fields.text: A deeply depressed Latino widower feels he needs help but he is ambivalent about psychotherapy. It is important for you to convey genuineness to this client because genuineness...
fields.explanation: Both A and B are true answers. A is the best answer because genuineness directly builds trust. This is almost obvious if you consider the opposite statement, "Deceit (or duplicity) builds trust," which is obviously untrue. B is a true statement in the sense that genuineness leads to trust which leads to self-revelation which leads to the potential for a deeper understanding of the client's psychodynamics, but B is not as directly true as A is. There is no empirical basis for assuming that C is true, and some empirical evidence that it is not true. D is incorrect because accurate empathy refers to the ability to use one's own imagination and experience to understand another's experience. This is not directly related to genuineness. It is possible to be genuine but lack empathy.

fields.text: What is the youngest age at which a minor can legally consent to treatment from a marriage and family therapist?
fields.explanation: A minor can consent to outpatient mental health treatment at the age of 12 if certain conditions apply. A is incorrect because a 10 year old child cannot consent to their own treatment. Consent must be provided by a parent or guardian. C and D are incorrect because, even though minors at these ages can consent to treatment, the question asks about the “youngest age” at which a minor can consent to their own treatment.

fields.text: A client has sought long term, insight oriented therapy to deal with her conflicted reactions to her recent divorce. During the initial session she changes the subject and focuses on discipline problems with her eight year old son. Your best course of action is to...
fields.explanation: The purpose of the initial session is usually focused on engagement ("an opportunity to build relationship") and initial assessment (“gather important assessment information”), not on changing the client. Both A and D are geared to changing things before the problem is understood or before the therapist has enough of a relationship with the client to be effective in changing things. C is incorrect because this divorced client is not seeking couples treatment.

fields.text: In order for a minor to legally consent to mental health treatment the minor must...
fields.explanation: Family Code Sec. 6924 (b) 1 requires that the minor be “mature enough to participate intelligently...” A is incorrect because a minor does not need to be the victim of child abuse in order to consent to treatment. Consent is valid from a minor if the minor would “present a danger of serious physical or mental harm to self or to others without such mental health treatment” regardless of the minor’s abuse history. B is incorrect because the minimum age for minor consent is 12. D is incorrect because the parent or guardian does not necessarily need to be involved in any way in the treatment, if their involvement would be inappropriate.

fields.text: Your 35 year old client is generally anxious and confused. He feels overwhelmed by changes in his life since his recent divorce, and blames his wife for the problems in their marriage. If you partialize objectives and tasks into subgoals and subtasks, you are likely to.
fields.explanation: This point is explicitly made in Crisis Intervention Theory. Partializing and prioritizing lead to a "cognitive grasp," just the opposite of confusing the client, so A is incorrect. Partializing and prioritizing is helpful and, therefore, might lead to a better relationship, but B is too indirectly related. C is incorrect because you should be able to relate your partialized and prioritized subgoals and subtasks to the big picture.

fields.text: Your very suspicious new psychotherapy client asks you many personal questions and wants to know what you expect of her during psychotherapy sessions. Your own expectations of the treatment process...
fields.explanation: Clarifying mutual role expectations is a standard component of the engagement process. The words "should never" are a clue that A is not correct. A therapist’s expectations of the therapy process might reflect countertransference at times, but even if they did, the client should still be able to know what they are. B is incorrect because clients need to know your expectations whether they ask or not. C is incorrect because your expectations of the therapy process can be expressed without any significant self-revelation.

fields.text: Your client is embarrassed by sweaty palms and a dry mouth in social situations involving new acquaintances. Your approach should be based on the fact that symptoms such as these are primarily controlled by...
fields.explanation: Sweaty palms and dry mouth are respondent behaviors. Respondent behavior responds to stimuli. In this case the stimulus involves being exposed to new acquaintances in a social situation. A is false because authority figures can attempt to control any kind of behavior. B is false. Reinforcement contingencies control operant, not respondent behavior. D is false because decision and free will can control both operant and respondent behavior, although many respondent behaviors might be very difficult to control by decision and free will.

fields.text: Your clinical approach emphasizes the importance of a therapeutic alliance and the client's development of his or her own problem formulation. You are probably using which of the following approaches?
fields.explanation: B, C and D are incorrect because these theories each offer a conceptual framework for formulating the nature of psychosocial problems. This framework is usually taught to clients, either through direct explanation and instruction, or through interpretations. The Humanistic Existential approach focuses on offering the kind of therapeutic alliance which will enhance the client's efforts to formulate the problem in a way that is _most meaningful from his or her own perspective. This is not a rigid and absolute distinction among these four approaches, but a matter of emphasis.

fields.text: If you use support and reassurance with a pervasively apprehensive and fearful client, your approach can....
fields.explanation: Any marriage and family text will attest to A. B is established in psychoanalytic theory. Many people will rule out C simply because support and reassurance seem to be positive techniques, but even a positive technique can have a downside. Support and reassurance can relieve some of the anxiety that might be motivating a client to work on problems and change. This can lead to a "flight into health" and the client can come to depend on the therapist’s support and reassurance, . rather than developing their own internal locus of control and judgment about their own adequacy. All three options are correct, so D is the best answer.

fields.text: You have begun to engage an angry and anxious client in long term, insight oriented psychotherapy with a goal of symptom reduction and personal development. The primary purpose of ventilation with such a client is...
fields.explanation: Ventilation may momentarily relieve a person of pent up frustrations and other problematic feelings, but the primary purpose, the farther reaching purpose, is to generate information about the client's thoughts, feelings, and dynamics so that they may be "worked through" therapeutically. C is incorrect because ventilation will not necessarily deepen the therapeutic alliance. For example, some clients come to feel ashamed and, therefore, more guarded with their therapist after having revealed more than they, in retrospect, feel that they should have. D is false because ventilation, if it is overdone, can actually cause a sense of overexposure and premature termination.

fields.text: You are serving a twenty-five client who has recently come to this country from her home in Guatemala. The client’s anxiety has been exacerbated by the stress of her immigration. You should...
fields.explanation: A is incorrect because it assumes that acculturation facilitates psychosocial adaptation in all cases, and because it presumes that the therapist should make this decision for the client. A person's degree of acculturation must be determined by the individual himself or herself. Many individuals prefer to live primarily within a cultural community with little contact with the multicultural mainstream community. The client in the question might even be expecting to return to his or her native country, in which case acculturation in this country would be less relevant. B is incorrect because it makes the assumptions made by answer A, and because it assumes that family members are the best source of cultural socialization. This is not always the case. Answer D is incorrect because, like answer A, it does not allow for self- determination. Answer C is based on the value of self-determination.

fields.text: Your amphetamine dependent client may experience substance induced delusions for how many months after discontinuing drug use?
fields.explanation: See the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders.

fields.text: Your 34 year old client has had a problem of hyperthyroidism dating back to early adolescence. Which of the following should you look for as a likely direct result of the client's hormone imbalance?
fields.explanation: Hyperthyroidism speeds up a person. It is commonly associated with anxiety, rarely with depression. A person can have psychotic experiences in association with high anxiety but the anxiety is primary and much more prevalent, therefore the best answer. D is false because cognitive dissonance refers to incongruity of a person's thoughts. This happens to all people and is not directly associated with hyperthyroidism.

fields.text: Your client reports that, in several settings, he has been smelling noxious fumes that nobody else smells. Your client should probably be treated for...
fields.explanation: Schizophrenic hallucinations are most likely to be auditory, although they may be visual as well. There is no specific association between dementia and olfactory hallucinations. Olfactory hallucinations (hallucinations involving the sense of smell) indicate an organic disturbance such as brain injury, physiological changes in brain chemistry, intoxication or withdrawal from intoxication.

fields.text: A young man seeks therapy to become more self-accepting and freely expressive. He says he has sought therapy from you because of your reputation for creative and inspirational interventions. The first thing you should do, in the initial interview, is...
fields.explanation: Considering the client's purpose in seeking therapy, the treatment is likely to be relatively lengthy. The therapist has time to allow the client's story to unfold as a way of engaging and assessing. B is incorrect because in the initial interview the therapist doesn't know enough about the client to recommend any particular solution. C is incorrect because the presenting problem hasn't yet been fully expressed. You can't focus on the development of something unless you know what that something is. There are clients, therapists and therapeutic approaches for which D might be a correct answer, but A is a much better reflection of the general standard of practice with a client who presents with this therapeutic goal. Besides, there are better ways to help a client take responsibility for resolving confusion than by remaining silent.

fields.text: African Americans are overdiagnosed in some categories, and underdiagnosed in others, because of...
fields.explanation: All three of these factors are commonly discussed in literature on culturally sensitive practice. While A, B and C are all true, D is the best answer because it is the most inclusive.

fields.text: Bill and Joan seek treatment for help with intractable and hostile arguments. Both Bill and Joan speak freely with you, and resist looking at one another during the session. In working with this couple in conjoint therapy, two therapists of both sexes should be used for the primary purpose of...
fields.explanation: When a man and a woman work with a single therapist of either gender, the odd person out generally feels some sense of threat as they scan for signs of alliance between their partner and the therapist. B is false because, although a client's tendency toward triangulation could be tested in a co-therapy situation, that is not . the primary purpose. Besides, triangulation could be tested when a single therapist works with a couple. C is a popular answer to this question. Co-therapists might attempt to model cross gender communication at times. However, A is considered a better answer because it relates to the entire course of therapy and because co-therapists of both sexes will accomplish the purpose expressed in A even in cases where there is no attempt to model cross gender communication. Note that this question might not make much sense if it applied to a client couple in which both partners were of the same sex, but most couples are two gender couples and questions should be answered in relation to the most commonly arising conditions. What is most often true will be considered to be the best answer.

fields.text: Your client explains that he is preoccupied with anger at a local journalist (whom he's never met) for unrequited love. Which of the following should you do initially?
fields.explanation: A is incorrect because, even though the therapist does not want to accept the delusion as reality, there is no need to challenge the client, certainly not initially. B is false because agreeing with a client's delusion is countertherapeutic. It might enhance some kind of alliance (or collusion), but it won't do anything to meaningfully enhance the therapeutic alliance. D is incorrect because it implies a challenge by identifying the belief as false, and because delusional clients don’t know" why they have come to hold their beliefs.

fields.text: Your client is a Latino man who firmly believes that he was impregnated on del Santo. He actively participates in a variety of activities within his ethnic community and has told others about his belief. You should treat his beliefs about pregnancy as...
fields.explanation: A is false because no known culture believes that men can become pregnant on their Dia del Santo. C is incorrect because an illusion is a distorted perception, not a false belief. D is incorrect because, even though this client's delusion might reflect an affirmation of faith, it is definitely a delusion.

fields.text: A client meeting the criteria for a somatization disorder is referred to you by a physician. Considering the likely psychodynamic purpose of somatization disorder symptoms, your best approach would be...
fields.explanation: The stem of the question gives you a clue by saying "Considering the likely psychodynamic purpose of somatization disorder symptoms..." Their psychodynamic purpose is to serve as a defense against anxiety. By supporting other more appropriate defenses the client will feel less need to somatisize. A is false because there's nothing about crisis in the question. B is false because analytic, interpretive therapy has a poor track record in resolving such symptoms. D might be helpful to some people who somatisize if their anxiety is related to unmet environmental needs, but there's nothing said about this client having this problem in the stem of the question.

fields.text: Childhood mental disorders may be caused by physical conditions, sex role strain, psychosocial stressors, genetics, traumas, some combination of these, or a variety of other causes. Childhood mental disorders are more prevalent among...
fields.explanation: The only childhood mental disorders in which girls predominate is Rett's Disorder, a rare condition. Boys predominate in mental retardation, attention deficit disorder (10 to 1), conduct disorder (12 to 1), overanxious disorder, tics (3 to 1), stuttering (4 to 1), functional enuresis (2 to 1), functional encopresis, sleepwalking, sleep terror, pervasive developmental disorder, and the specific developmental disorders.

fields.text: “Telemedicine” applies to certain forms of clinical practice which are governed by California state law. What does “telemedicine” refer to?
fields.explanation: Telemedicine is addressed in Business and Professions Code Sec. 2290.5 which states “For the purposes of this section, "telemedicine" means A the practice of health care delivery, diagnosis, consultation, treatment, transfer of medical data, and education using interactive audio, video, or data communications.” A is incorrect because telemedicine is not limited to prescription of medicine. B is incorrect because telemedicine only applies to interactive use of audio or video communications. D is incorrect because telemedicine is much more inclusive than counseling by telephone. C is a better answer because it is more inclusive and because it reflects the actual definition stated in the law.

fields.text: Your client’s social and occupational functioning have been impaired by high anxiety following a very stressful event. You will most likely need to treat this client for...
fields.explanation: A key phrase in the stem of the question is most likely. These symptoms could be associated with PTSD, but because adjustment disorder is much more prevalent than PTSD, they are more likely to reflect adjustment disorder. No diagnosis is a possibility, but given the severity and acuity of the symptoms, and resulting impairment, B is probably a better answer. D is incorrect because cyclothymia is a mood disorder which is not characterized by these anxiety symptoms.

fields.text: The law requires that, prior to engaging in the practice of “telemedicine” you must inform your client that...
fields.explanation: Business and Professions Code Sec. 2290.5 requires that telemedicine clients be informed of the fact that “all existing confidentiality protections apply.” B is incorrect because the law makes no exception for telemedicine in the application of all existing confidentiality protection. They apply without limitation. C is incorrect because the law does not require that you inform your clients regarding which of your treatment processes and procedures have or have not demonstrated efficacy. D is incorrect because the law does not require any special training in order to engage in the kinds of electronic communications with clients that would constitute telemedicine. To the extent that special training might be needed for a particular form of telemedicine communications, the marriage and family therapist has an ethical obligation to obtain such training prior to using this or any other treatment process or procedure.

fields.text: Your client is a married man who has had sexual relations with his 10 year old daughter. Chances are greatest that your client...
fields.explanation: The key words in the question's stem are “chances are greatest.” Although A, Band C are true for some incest offenders, none of those choices are true for most. Most incest perpetrators are heterosexual who have problematic personality traits. However, by virtue of a diagnostic criterion introduced in the DSM IV TR any sexual behavior with a child constitutes pedophilia if the perpetrator has also experienced 6 or more months of recurrent, intense sexually arousing fantasies or sexual urges involving a prepubescent child. 26 . The correct answer is A. B and C are incorrect because the privilege usually applies in civil and criminal trials. Such protection is one of the major purposes of having a privileged communication law. D is incorrect in most cases. Note, however, that privilege does not apply when the patient is under age 16 and disclosure is in the best interest of the child.

fields.text: You may reveal a client’s privileged communication in the State of California without your client’s consent under which of the following conditions?
fields.explanation: NOT AVAILABLE

fields.text: In order to involuntarily detain a suicidal individual under Welfare and Institutions Code Section 5150, the person’s danger to self must be...
fields.explanation: The danger must be due to a mental disorder. A is incorrect because the 5150 law applies regardless of the duration of a danger. C and D are incorrect because a police officer, for example, may involuntarily hold a person without a mental health professional's evaluation.

fields.text: “The Domestic Violence Reporting Act,” Penal Code Sec. 11160...
fields.explanation: Penal Code Sec. 11160 rarely if ever applies to marriage and family therapists because this law only requires reports from health practitioners who treat wounds and injuries. A is incorrect because marriage and family therapists are defined as health practitioners under this law. B and C are incorrect because the law does not apply on the condition of providing psychotherapy or treatment of psychological trauma...only on the condition of providing medical treatment for a physical wound or injury.

fields.text: When conducting a mental status exam, you should distinguish delusions from which of the following similar and related symptoms?
fields.explanation: A is incorrect because illusions are distorted perceptions and have little to do with delusions. C is false because a person may be preoccupied with their delusion but, unlike a delusion, a true obsession is ego dystonic. D is false because catatonia has nothing to do with what a person believes. An overvalued idea, like a delusion, does express what a person believes. It is a false idea that is held with less rigidity than a delusion. See the glossary of the Diagnostic Manual for more information.

fields.text: During substance withdrawal, your client presents with fatigue, psychomotor agitation, hypersomnia, and delusions. No other somatic features are prominent. Which kind of drug has your client been using?
fields.explanation: See the Diagnostic Manual for more information about withdrawal symptoms of the various types of drugs.

fields.text: Mrs. K. is a middle aged African American client whose level of distress is disturbing but not disabling. During the initial phase of therapy, reducing her sense of anxiety through support and reassurance can...
fields.explanation: The key words in this question's stem are "level of distress is disturbing but not disabling," and "reducing her sense of anxiety" through support and reassurance. If Mrs. K's level of distress were disabling, then reducing the anxiety might actually help to increase motivation. But since it wasn't disabling, it is more likely that her level of anxiety was motivating her to change. B is incorrect because overventilation is much more likely to result from high anxiety than from having one's anxiety reduced. Support and reassurance might lead to a variety of changes that might ultimately lead to expanded emotional awareness, but this is not a direct effect. Reduced motivation for change can be a direct effect. Support and reassurance play such a small role in the overall therapeutic strategy for restructuring character that D is not a good answer.

fields.text: Tony’s life appears to be a series of crises which the client does not manage very well. However, he generally has no significant perceptual distortions and no signs of thought disorder. Suddenly he becomes wildly agitated and delusional. The client is most likely experiencing...
fields.explanation: A is false because being delusional and hyperventilating are too remotely related. B is not the best answer because the sudden onset and wild agitation are much more likely related to a brief psychosis than to schizophreniform disorder. D is incorrect because the presence of delusions essentially rules out adjustment disorder.

fields.text: Privileged communication does not apply to a client of a marriage and family therapist if the client...
fields.explanation: This exception is explicitly listed in the law, Evidence Code Sec. 16 - 27. B is incorrect because a minor is entitled to privileged communication unless the minor “is a child under the age of 16 and the psychotherapist has reasonable cause to believe that the patient has been the victim of a crime and that disclosure of the communication is in the best interest of the child.” All other minors under all other circumstances are covered by privileged communication. C is incorrect because the law doesn’t recognize a family as being a client. This is a clinical concept. Under the law each member of a client family is a client, unless you have designated a family member as “the client” and others as “collaterals” with whom you are communicating on behalf of “the client.” D is incorrect because clients are protected by privileged communication whether or not they are fully or effectively engaged in therapy.

fields.text: Your client has a strong tendency to use primitive defense mechanisms. Based on this information, which of the following would you most likely expect to observe in your client?
fields.explanation: Primitive defenses are those which are available early in the course of development. B is incorrect because the capacity for logical thought doesn't develop until well after the capacity for denial (e. g. simply closing one's eyes as a way of denying reality, as often happens in infancy or toddlerhood). C is false because sublimation is considered to be the most highly developed and adaptive defense mechanism and we need a sense of interpersonal boundaries to experience identification. Introj ection occurs unconsciously and ignores interpersonal boundaries. D is incorrect because impulse control and sense of reality are ego functions, not ego defense mechanisms.

fields.text: Mr. G. is a client who has recently immigrated to this country under stress. He is of a culture other than your own. When conducting a mental status examination you should be especially careful when interpreting the client’s response to which of these MSE techniques?
fields.explanation: A is incorrect because numerical calculations are essentially the same in all cultures. The client's response to a request to make a calculation may be influenced by the client's culture, but the actual calculation should be similar across cultures. It is true that educational attainment across cultures varies, and education can affect calculation ability, but this is not a cultural factor per se. B is incorrect because most cultures use the same calendar for purposes of daily commerce and cross cultural communication, even though some cultures use unique calendars for marking religious or spiritual time. C is incorrect because this is a nonverbal task which is less likely than others to be influenced by culture. D is correct because proverbs and their interpretations vary substantially across cultures. It is possible that a client of another culture may not have even heard the proverb presented by a clinician prior to the time of the interview, whereas clients of the same culture may be very familiar with the proverb and its common interpretations.

fields.text: Your client is concerned about a persistent problem of guilt. He avoids competition and is righteously moralistic when referring to the successful people he knows. If you were taking a developmental history, What age should you focus on in order to discover the source of this client's underlying conflict or fixation?
fields.explanation: The qualities of guilt, competition, and morality are all associated with the Oedipal complex or Electra complex that arise in Freud's (Oedipal stage) or Erikson's (initiative vs. guilt) third stage of development.

fields.text: The conflict between identity versus role confusion can cause problems for your clients at which stage of life?
fields.explanation: The key words in the stem are "can cause problems." In introducing his eight stages of development Erikson explains that the core conflict of any one stage could arise at any time in life. When Erikson says that the conflict between identity and role confusion is the most prominent conflict of adolescence he does not intend to say that it only arises in adolescence.

fields.text: One of the treatment plan objectives for Janet, a 23 year old, calls for increased capacity for empathy. When evaluating increased capacity for empathy in this client, the most important consideration should be...
fields.explanation: Answers A and B would be important in conducting academic research or research where it was important to generalize findings to others, but evaluating an individual client's progress is a matter of clinical concern. C is incorrect because human subjects review committees are not required for informal evaluation within a clinical relationship, even though evaluative observations and judgments are based on principles used in formal research. D is correct because the indicators you use to evaluate client progress must be valid indicators of the ultimate clinical objective.

fields.text: When providing service to an individual at the request of a third party a marriage and family therapist should...
fields.explanation: The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that “Marriage and family therapists, upon agreeing to provide services to a person or entity at the request of a third party, clarify, to the extent feasible and at the outset of the service, the nature of the relationship with each party and the limits of confidentiality.” A is incorrect because sometimes the third party is entitled to confidential information, as in the case of parents who have given consent to the treatment of their three year old child, or in some circumstances where the therapist is appointed by order of the court. C is incorrect because the referring party does not usually become the therapist’s client. For example, a referring primary care physician does not become the therapist’s client, and the therapist has no treatment responsibility to the physician as an individual. D is incorrect because the therapist and client need to determine what information, if any, will be provided, to the third party. The client might consent to the release of more or less information than that specified in answer D.

fields.text: The Andersons are a couple who have sought your clinical services to resolve a problem of persistent, intractable, and often violent fights among the siblings in the family. In taking a Strategic Family Therapy approach, you should recognize that the troubled children in this family are...
fields.explanation: Strategic Family Therapy recognizes a core principle of Social Systems Theory; that every member of a system affects every other member. Children affect parents, as parents affect children.

fields.text: Mr. G. is an anxious client who has sought therapy for help in overcoming self- defeating behavior that interferes with career success. However, the client becomes silent almost every time the issue of authority relationships with supervisors arises. This client's silence probably represents...
fields.explanation: Confusion (A) might lead to confused statements and questions from the client, not necessarily silence. There is no direct connection between the client's silence and either insight development (answer B) or engagement (answer C). But silence is a common way of resisting exploration of threatening issues in therapy.

fields.text: An anxious client sought therapy for help in overcoming self-defeating behavior that interferes with career success. However, the client becomes silent almost every time the issue of authority relationships with supervisors arises. As this client's therapist your best course of action would be to...
fields.explanation: B is not a good answer because the client probably does not yet have a clear sense of having a problem with authority relationships. Such an explanation would likely be little more than an intellectual discourse with no insight or gut level integration by the client. C is not a good answer because, if the silence is in fact a resistance, then whatever emerges from that silence is likely to be a distraction, another form of resistance. D is not a good answer because this intervention is likely to draw a pro forma compliance without any real working through.

fields.text: You will most likely need to help your clients deal with the experience of a sense of rejection or narcissistic injury to self-esteem during...
fields.explanation: A sense of rejection and narcissistic injury could arise at any time but it is most likely to arise during termination when the client's dependency relationship is frustrated. Also, any fantasies about having had a personal relationship with the therapist (outside the bounds of the therapeutic contract and professional boundaries) are challenged.

fields.text: As his therapist your unconscious, distorted perceptions of your rebellious adolescent client are...
fields.explanation: A could be a true answer, but it is not the best answer because A is sometimes true but C is always true. A transference (B) is a client's unconscious, distorted perceptions of a therapist. D is false because therapists are only human and will have unconscious, distorted perceptions regardless of their theoretical orientation.

fields.text: Mr. P, a 63 year old patient with vascular dementia and a recent heart attack, needs treatment for marital problems which have a negative effect on his medical condition. This individuals mental disorder is the result of....
fields.explanation: Vascular dementia is also known as multi-infarct dementia. An infarct is a stroke....a destruction of tissue as the result of obstructed blood flow to the tissue. See the Diagnostic Manual for more information.

fields.text: You have seen Tom M in long term, insight oriented psychotherapy for three years. Several weeks ago you raised the issue of termination. Since then he began to devalue you and, for the first time, denies the benefits of his over-all course of therapy. You should treat this behavior as...
fields.explanation: B and C are not good answers because this reaction is common at the time of termination, even from clients with little psychopathology or clients who have uncovered their significant unresolved conflicts. In arguing for answer B, one could say that everyone has some significant unresolved conflicts. That may be true, but even if it is true there is no reason to think that the client's devaluations at the time of termination are an indication of those unresolved conflicts. In most cases, the most likely reason for the devaluing is described in answer A. D is incorrect because the devaluing expected of a person with borderline personality disorder would have likely shown up earlier, and would not simply be triggered by a specific event like termination.

fields.text: In reviewing the clinical documentation on a newly referred Vietnamese family you notice frequent references to “double bind communication” between the parents and their oldest daughter. This kind of communication should be treated as...
fields.explanation: Experimental neurosis is what happens when the subject in a study is punished for exercising either one of two options when only two options are available. The term could also apply in situations where the subject is rewarded for exercising either option. B is false because, even though double bind communication was once postulated as the cause of schizophrenia, this hypothesis has not withstood the test of time and empirical study. There is no particular association between double bind communication and either Southeast Asian cultures or multiple personality disorder.

fields.text: Your client is a depressed sixty-seven year old man who needs a referral to a bereavement support group. The first thing you should do when making this referral is to...
fields.explanation: A is false because, even though it might be a good idea to discuss the referral with the resource before presenting it to the client in some cases, this does not usually need be done. B is false because, even though it might also be a good idea to visit a resource, it is often logistically impossible in the real world. Most marriage and family therapists have better things to do with their time. D is false because the therapist has no way of knowing whether or not the referral resource will be effective for the client in question. The therapist should let the client know why the resource is appropriate to the client's needs and preferences to enhance the chances of the client engaging with the referral resource.

fields.text: Your initial session with a family includes two parents, their three children, a grandparent, and an uncle. All family members live in the same house. In the course of your interview the uncle, a skilled carpenter, notices the damage to your window frame, and offers to fix it as payment for services to the family. What are you permitted to do?
fields.explanation: Although the AAMFT Code of Ethics allows for barter in payment for marriage and family therapy services under certain circumstances, the code does not permit bartering if the professional relationship would be distorted. The code also prohibits providing services that create a conflict of interest that may impair work performance or clinical judgment. The kind of barter arrangement described in this question could distort the professional relationship and constitute a conflict of interest. This is an especially problematic type of barter relationship, or dual relationship, in which services are offered in payment. A is incorrect because your decision to exclude the uncle from sessions may be influenced by your desire to receive his services. Also, even if you believe he does not need to be involved in sessions now, as a live in member of a troubled family, the need for his participation might arise at any time. B is incorrect because the family members do not have the authority to relieve you of your ethical obligations. D is incorrect because the concept of "incapacity to make informed decisions" applies to exceptionally impaired individuals suffering from conditions such as dementia or acute episodes of psychosis, not to members of troubled families.

fields.text: Billy, a child with an adjustment disorder, is referred to you for play therapy by his mother’s therapist. You should not use play therapy with a child unless....
fields.explanation: The primary purpose of play therapy is to give a person the opportunity to express thoughts and feelings through action, not only words. This can benefit some clients, both as an assessment technique and as a treatment technique. A is incorrect because play therapy can be used with a person of any age who can benefit hom such nonverbal expression. B is incorrect because even a verbal child may have certain thoughts and feelings that can best be expressed through the action and interaction of play. C is incorrect because, even though a parent or guardian does need to give permission for treatment in most cases, the parent or guardian does not need to give permission for every specific technique used in the course of treatment.

fields.text: Four suicidal clients have applied for service at your community mental health clinic. All of them can describe a method for taking their own lives and all are similarly depressed. Which client is at highest risk for suicide and, therefore, should be seen first if you can see only one client today?
fields.explanation: All four clients are at risk. The middle aged male who is living alone is at highest risk. Relative to that individual, the 19 year old female is at less risk because of her gender and age. Also note that she wants to kill herself to influence another person's feelings, not because she wants to die. The 43 year old male (C) is at less risk because he is living with a significant other. The 44 year old female (D) is at less risk because of gender. Also note that she is frightened by her suicidal thoughts. She does not welcome them as a way of resolving a difficult life problem.

fields.text: You are treating a paranoid and narcissistic young man who insists on seeing his clinical records. He claims that he, as the client, “owns” the information in the record. Your response should be based on the fact that the party who"owns" the information revealed by the client to a therapist is...
fields.explanation: The therapist, the therapist's agency, and (on behalf of the agency) the agency's board of directors owns the physical record, not the information in it.

fields.text: When obtaining informed consent from a client who is about to be engaged in an unusual treatment technique, which of the following factors is not a necessary element of the informed consent?
fields.explanation: Notice the word "not" in the question. A is incorrect because, if the consent is coerced, it is submission and not consent. B is incorrect because, if the client does not have accurate information, the consent is not informed consent. C is incorrect because, if the client is unable to understand and reason about the decision, the consent is not informed. If the informed consent is not documented, however, it is still informed consent. Some employers might require documentation, and it is always a good practice to document the informed consent. But the other three response options are principles of law more fundamental than an agency's requirements of staff or "good practice."

fields.text: Your client presents a complex case in which he has suffered all of the following stressors over the past four years. Which of these should you view as the most severe stressor and, therefore, the one most likely to contribute to the client’s multiple symptoms?
fields.explanation: This answer is based on the well known Holmes and Rahe Scale for assessing the severity of psychosocial stressors. The only stressor with a higher rating than divorce is the death of a spouse (not one of the response options for this question).

fields.text: David, age 9, has had his right leg amputated after a cancerous tumor was found. His parents constantly try to cheer him up and they say that they "don't understand why he doesn't respond...after all, the doctor said it hasn't spread." You should view David's parents’ behavior as...
fields.explanation: A is ruled out by the fact that the parents say they "don't understand." An empathic response implies deep understanding. C is ruled out because there is no specific indication of mixed messages. D is a possible answer because trying to cheer someone up can be supportive. However, in this case it is apparently being done in a way that fails to accept (denies) the child's sense of sadness and loss. That is not supportive.

fields.text: You are preparing your client to anticipate some of the consequences of a leg amputation that he is expected to undergo within a few days. You should let your client know that, as a result of a leg amputation he is most likely to experience...
fields.explanation: Almost all individuals who have limb amputations experience some degree of phantom limb syndrome, that is, feeling as if the limb were still there. The likelihood of low self-esteem or disturbed object relations will depend on the client’s personality. Low self-esteem or disturbed object relations are possible after an amputation but not as likely as phantom limb syndrome. Cognitive dissonance is only tangentially related to this situation.

fields.text: You are practicing psychodynamic psychotherapy with a client who has serious conflicts in relation to competition, winning and losing. In analyzing your client's conflicts you should pay special attention to his development at about the age of...
fields.explanation: Competition, winning and losing are all features of the Oedipal or Electra Complex. According to classical Psychoanalytic and Ego Psychology theory this arises during the third stage of development, approximately ages 3 or 4 through 6.

fields.text: Donald K. is an emotionally labile client who rapidly cycles between idealizing and devaluing you as the therapist. He complains of a persistent sense of “emptiness” and is confused about his identity and purpose in life. Your best course of action with Donald will be...
fields.explanation: This client's description suggests borderline personality disorder. Some therapists have specialized training in depth psychotherapy techniques (B through D) with borderline clients, but most do not. Those therapists might use interpretation or confrontation. In most cases, however, the inner turmoil of the borderline personality disorder is best approached with reality oriented therapy. Generally, the treatment objectives will be focused on reality problem resolution rather than personality reconstruction. As with all questions, it is best to give the answer that would be true for most marriage and family therapists, even though exceptions may exist.

fields.text: Your client sought therapy for help in dealing with his many unsatisfying and “shallow” relationships. However, in the course of treatment you learn that the client experiences discrete periods of high anxiety with sudden onset and no apparent trigger. You should rule out, or arrange to rule out...
fields.explanation: This client's description suggests panic attacks. A, B, or D could conceivably be related to panic attacks, but the relationship is more remote than it is with hyperthyroidism. Note that hypothyroidism can also be associated with anxiety, but is more often associated with depression.

fields.text: Your client is a young man with schizophrenia. In developing an outpatient treatment plan it would be best to emphasize....
fields.explanation: B is incorrect because double bind communication is not . etiologically related to schizophrenia, as once thought. If it is an issue at all for a particular client, it is likely to be so only as a peripheral issue. Interpreting delusional themes (C) is contraindicated in schizophrenia. It could precipitate inner turmoil, confusion and decompensation. Meeting the client's housing needs (D) is a true answer but it is not the best answer. Not all clients with schizophrenia will need help with housing, whereas all clients with schizophrenia will need help with reality problem solving (A). Also note that reality problem solving includes housing needs among many other possible needs.

fields.text: You are providing clinical services to clients in a day treatment program, all of whom experience "sundowner syndrome." You will probably need to treat your clients for psychosocial problems associated with...
fields.explanation: Sundowner syndrome, a feature of organic dementia, is apparently due to the greater attention to intemal stimuli when worldly distractions are reduced in the evening. No explanation, however, has been empirically confirmed.

fields.text: You are leading a recently formed psychotherapy group for women who have been sexually molested as children and who now experience the consequences of their former abuse. During the exploring and testing phase of your group's development you should...
fields.explanation: A is false because conflict will be inevitable at this stage and does not need to be encouraged. B is false because if conflict is suppressed it will not be worked through to resolution. D is false because group members need to discover and establish their own leadership hierarchies. This is one of the positive outcomes of the exploring and testing phase of group development.

fields.text: Mrs. Roth complains about her 26 year old daughter, Lisa, who has been irresponsible and has maintained a dependent relationship with her mother. She seeks your help in figuring out whether or not Lisa might be abusing drugs. Your first course of action, in the initial session, should be to...
fields.explanation: It's important to note the words “first” and “initial session” in the question's stem. Answers A through C are geared to actively helping the client change before getting to know what the problem really is, what changes are needed, and before establishing the kind of therapeutic relationship that would make these active change oriented techniques effective. First, time is needed for engaging and assessing. That includes observing the client.

fields.text: Your client lives with her hostile and verbally abusive 26 year old daughter. By the sixth session it appears likely that your client’s daughter is chemically dependent. By this time you and your client have agreed that the primary focus of therapy will be to develop autonomy in her relationship with her daughter. You should encourage your client to...
fields.explanation: A is not a good answer because your client may not be able to determine when her daughter is clean and sober and when she is not. But she will be able to determine whether or not her daughter has paid the rent and engaged in acceptable behavior (as is called for in C). B encourages the client to take responsibility for the way her 26 year old daughter lives her life, thereby reinforcing the existing problem of codependency. D is not a good answer because your client needs to learn to manage her life and the consequences of her daughter's behavior as it affects her life. C will do that directly. D might not do that at all. Besides, there is probably no way your client will ever know how much of her daughter’s dysfunctional behavior is due to her parenting behavior, to other childhood caretakers, to genetic predisposition, to society's norms and values, to chance encounters with drugs, or to her daughter’s personal choice and exercise of free will.

fields.text: You are providing therapy to the codependent mother of a chemically dependent daughter. Her goal in therapy is to establish autonomy in her relationship with her daughter. You should plan to terminate therapy with your client When...
fields.explanation: B is a poor answer because Mrs. Roth's need for treatment is not simply dependent on her daughter's need for treatment. C is a poor answer for two reasons; the dynamic source of a problem is never resolved in most cases and such a character restructuring goal seems out of proportion to the way the problem was initially described, with a focus on practical living arrangements and the day to day mother- daughter relationship. D is a poor answer because her feeling of being ready to terminate could arise as a resistance to change or she might enjoy the therapeutic relationship and never feel ready to terminate. A links termination to a specific and reasonable goal for this case.

fields.text: Linda is a pregnant 14 year old girl who comes to see you for help in making a decision regarding abortion. She is preoccupied with the possibility of punishment from her father, whom she says is "always on me." You should...
fields.explanation: A is false because most people would not have a reasonable suspicion of abuse based on the limited information in the stem. C is false because it would imply divulging a client's identity before having the reasonable suspicion that gives a therapist permission to divulge an identity. D is false because you only need a reasonable suspicion, not clear evidence of abuse to warrant making a report. B is correct because it expresses exactly what California law requires.

fields.text: You are working with several hostile adolescent males who engage in antisocial behavior and who have each had several arrests. When you use confrontation as a psychotherapeutic technique with these clients you should...
fields.explanation: Explanation is the technique described in A. Challenging a person to engage in socially appropriate or constructive behavior (C) is what we often mean when we use the term "confrontation" colloquially, but not as a psychotherapeutic technique. Technically, confrontation means making the client aware of inconsistencies; for example, inconsistencies within his or her perceptions, or between perceptions and objective facts, or between his/her verbal and non-verbal communication. D is incorrect because you can offer support to a client, even while making the client aware of inconsistencies.

fields.text: In the course of providing professional assistance it is unethical for a marriage and family therapist to discriminate on the basis of sexual orientation...
fields.explanation: The AAMFT Code of Ethics prohibits discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and makes no exceptions. A and B are incorrect because it is unethical to discriminate on the basis of sexual orientation in the course of providing professional assistance, regardless of one’s religion or ethnic culture. C is incorrect because an MFT’s training should enable the individual to work with a diverse caseload of clients. If an MFT lacks training in a specialized aspect of practice that is associated with sexual orientation or any other human diversity issue, the MFT may not provide service on the grounds that the required service is outside of one’s scope of competence. But this question is not about a specialized aspect of practice. It is about providing services to a diverse range of potential clients, and it is about discrimination. Actions legitimately taken on the grounds of scope of competence do not constitute discrimination.

fields.text: In your psychoeducational group for mothers of young infants, you should explain that, in the healthy infant, the notion that objects exist apart from oneself develops at about the age of....
fields.explanation: This fact is reported by Jean Piaget, and confirmed by many others.

fields.text: An MFT Intern approaches you to receive qualifying supervision toward licensure. She wants you to focus on helping her develop better treatment plans with her clients. As
fields.explanation: This requirement is set forth in Business and Professions Code Section 4996.13. A and C are incorrect because they describe a consultation relationship, not supervision. D is incorrect because the Associate may be employed by you and, in a private practice, must be employed by you.

fields.text: In taking a Social Systems approach to therapy with an enmeshed family you should expect that all of the following are true except...
fields.explanation: Notice the word "except" in the question. All three points - - A through C -- are well established in both General Systems Theory and Social Systems Theory. D, however, is incorrect because all systems need a mechanism for social control, that is, for maintaining a pattern of roles and norms.

fields.text: In your work with an intensive, insight oriented psychotherapy group you should recognize that all of the following contribute to the group's capacity to promote positive change except...
fields.explanation: Notice the word "except" in the question. Cohesion (A) is a key to promoting positive change. Open airing of conflict and crisis (B) are an essential aspects of group development that makes cohesion possible. Clarity and consensus of purpose (D) also lead to, and result from, cohesion. A fluid dominance hierarchy, however, arrests group development and leaves members with an insecure sense of chaos.

fields.text: Your client has been arrested for physical assaults against his wife. He now expresses remorse and claims that he will never again engage in such violent behavior. Which of the following qualities is least indicative of high recidivism risk for this client?
fields.explanation: Notice the word "least" in this question. Domestic violence perpetrators commonly buy into polarized sex role stereotypes. A more balanced androgynous sex role self-image reduces the risk of acting out the more destructive elements of a stereotypical male role. Undifferentiated self-concept (A) is a sign of poor ego functioning and leaves a person vulnerable to anxiety, as does an overwhelming sense of guilt(B). It is best to feel guilt but not be overwhelmed by it. In a domestic violence perpetrator such anxiety is likely to be acted out in further violence. Ifthe family blames the victim (D) the perpetrator will feel a sense of permission, or even expectation to act out, and risk is increased. C is the only factor listed that would decrease risk.

fields.text: A psychiatrist is treating a woman for major depressive disorder and refers the client to you for concurrent psychotherapy. Which of the following symptoms would you least expect to find when you assess this client?
fields.explanation: Notice the word "least" in this question. C and D are classic symptoms of depression. B is often associated with depression when it is coupled with anxiety. Hyperventilation (A) is associated with anxiety, not depression.

fields.text: You are working with a client who is twenty years younger than you. The client is also of another ethnic culture. You must first establish a basis for the client’s identification with you in order to effectively use which of the following treatment techniques?
fields.explanation: A person will only follow the modeling of someone with whom he or she identifies. Interpretation can be accepted from anyone with credibility, whether we identify with them or not. Effective communication happens all the time between people with or without mutual identification. Introjection is a subconscious process that is independent of the more conscious and highly developed ego function of identification.

fields.text: As a staff member of a community mental health crisis intervention clinic, all of your treatment plans should... .
fields.explanation: A is false because, even though the client should participate in and agree to the service plan, the client should not determine it. The client is only one of several parties who may have a legitimate interest in the service plan. Others are the therapist, the agency, and third party payors. C is false because it presumes too much. Not all clients have a need to improve self-esteem. D is false because there is no optimal number of objectives that applies to all cases. B is a basic principle of treatment planning.

fields.text: You are interviewing a nine year old child who has been sexually abused by her father. She states that she has been afraid to reveal the secret because of pressure from both parents. When interviewing this child, you should not say which of the following?
fields.explanation: Note the words "should not" in the question. A should be said because it normalizes the problem and helps the child overcome the sense that she is alone with her problem. C and D are the kinds of questions that may be needed to gather important assessment information. You should be careful with statements like C because it could be a leading question. However, it would not be a leading question if the child first told you that her father "said things that made me afraid to tell." B should not be said in any case because the therapist has no basis for giving this kind of reassurance. Whether or not the father goes to jail is a matter out of the therapist’s hands.

fields.text: You are working with a middle aged man in insight oriented psychotherapy. The client seeks to overcome a long standing problem of dependency on the women in his life. If you use "why questions” regarding the client’s underlying motivations, you should expect that your questions will tend to...
fields.explanation: Why questions about underlying motivations call for cause-effect inferences about something very abstract. Few of us can answer such - questions with valid and reliable information (B). C is false because such questions, like any questions, may or may not reflect the interviewer's countertransferences. D is incorrect because "why" questions may or may not focus on affect. A is correct because, in our culture, we often challenge a person's behavior with rhetorical "why" questions. For example, "Why must you be so..." "Why don't you ever...." This commonly provokes a defensive response.

fields.text: The Ramirez family is referred to you for psychosocial evaluation and possible family therapy by the court. In the course of interviewing family members to determine the circumstances of this domestic violence situation, you should avoid all of the following except...
fields.explanation: Notice the word "except" in the question. Keep in mind that the purpose of your interview is to determine the circumstances of a situation. A and C will lead the client to tell you what you are wanting or expecting to hear, not the facts. B will be confusing. Open ended questions, on the other hand, do not lead the client into any particular answer and they leave the client free to say as much or as little as they find necessary.

fields.text: You are working in a treatment program for incest perpetrators. The clinical record indicates that your new client has a problem of “regressed pedophilia,” not fixated pedophilia. He does not meet the criteria for a paraphilia diagnosis. This means all of the following are true except...
fields.explanation: Notice the word "except" in the question, and note that diagnosable pedophilia is a paraphilia. D is not a true statement because either regressed or fixated pedophiles may use primitive defenses when sexually aroused. A through C are true statements by definition. In the fixated pedophile, unlike the regressed pedophile, the primary sexual orientation is to children, not agemates. Their pedophilia is a persistent quality of their character, not a reaction to stress. Their pedophilic interests are persistent &om childhood or adolescence, as with the personality disorders.

fields.text: An eighty year old man is referred to you for a psychosocial evaluation. The referring internist has been concerned about the client’s apparent depression, but thinks that the client might also be experiencing cognitive problems. In making a differential diagnosis of “organic dementia” in this client you should rule out...
fields.explanation: Organic dementia and clinical depression (a mood disorder) often look similar in the elderly. There is no particular connection between organic dementia and the other three response options.

fields.text: Under the California Confidentiality of Medical Information Act, when a person requesting information about a client’s outpatient psychotherapy submits a written request for consent to the client, the request must state...
fields.explanation: Under the COMIA law the person requesting the . information must specifically describe the information being requested, its specific intended use, and the fact that it will not be used for any purpose other than its intended use. B is incorrect because the person making the request is not required to reveal their credentials to the client and, in fact, doesn’t even need to have any formal credentials. C is incorrect because the written request must state how long the information will be kept, but there is no requirement that it must state the date by which the information must be received in the first place. D is incorrect because California’s COMIA law does not refer to HIPAA, and the person receiving the information might not even be a covered entity under HIPAA. For example, an attorney receiving confidential psychotherapy information is not covered by HIPAA and would not be bound to use and protect the information in the same way that a health care provider would under HIPAA.

fields.text: In assessing a 50 year old depressed client for suicide risk, which question should you use to draw the most valid and reliable information?
fields.explanation: B requires the client to make a judgment about what is a serious attempt. The client's standard for this and your own (or any two clients‘ standards) might be very different. D is incorrect because "why" questions generate defensiveness and abstract answers, not reliable and valid information. A simply calls on the client to describe their previous behavior. It does not call on the client to make a judgment about the behavior's significance. The interviewer can then rate the degree of risk using a standardized instrument or assessment framework.

fields.text: Your client is a sixty year old cardiac patient who takes long pauses before answering each of your questions. Which should you consider to be the least likely explanation?
fields.explanation: Note the words "least likely" in the stem. Thought blocking most often occurs in the middle of a thought (or sentence), not at the beginning. Therefore, it is the least likely answer. B is incorrect because depression can cause a delayed response to a question because of psychomotor retardation. C is incorrect because obsessive compulsiveness can cause a delay as the individual seeks the perfect thing to say before saying it. D is incorrect because low self-esteem's shyness and fear of ridicule or rejection can delay the answers to question.

fields.text: In the course of consulting with you, a colleague reveals that his client, Mrs. Kahn, has just received a Presidential Citation for her local civic work. You believe she would be a good asset to your agency's board of directors. When you contact the chair of the board to make your suggestion you...
fields.explanation: You should respect confidential information shared by colleagues in the course of their professional relationships and transactions. B is ' incorrect for the reason that A is correct. C is incorrect because the confidentiality of information is not limited to derogatory information. It applies to any information received from a client or colleague about a client. D is incorrect because neither you nor your colleague should be contacting the client about this issue. If you were to contact the client it could. damage the trusting relationship between the client and your colleague. Your colleague should not seek the client's consent because such action would involve a dual relationship. Your colleague's purpose with this client is to help her resolve her psychosocial problems and achieve her treatment goals and objectives, not to develop an agency's board of directors.

fields.text: The client, a 45 year old man, brings his aging father to the front desk of the medical clinic. He says "My father has worked hard and paid taxes all his life. He has paid his health insurance premiums without missing a single one for over twenty years. He's entitled to see the doctor immediately." You should assess these statements as evidence of...
fields.explanation: Flight of ideas (A) is a nearly continuous flow of accelerated speech with abrupt changes from topic to topic. These abrupt changes are not reflected here. B is false because there is no evidence of a commonly recognized false fixed belief, firmly held despite being presented with evidence to the contrary. The thinking is illogical, however. The speaker's premises may be presumed to be true. However, there is no logical connection between working hard, paying taxes, and paying premiums regularly on the one hand, and being entitled to see a doctor immediately on the other hand. Even if we think that this should be true, it is not. Being entitled to see a doctor immediately is determined by the doctor's availability, the relative urgency of the problem, the needs of others who are waiting to see the doctor, and other logistical factors. D is incorrect because ideas of reference refer to the assumption that other people are doing What they are doing or saying what they are saying because of oneself.

fields.text: The client, a 45 year old man, says "Don't touch my hat because if you do I will die. This hat was made in Peru, the heart of the Andean coca trade. I have a terrible heart condition and I would not survive if you were to touch this hat." You should assess these statements as indicating...
fields.explanation: A is false because the individual is staying on a topic. C is false because there is no evidence of being derailed in the middle of a thought. The individual's thoughts hold together to make a point, but it is a patently false point. D is incorrect because hallucinations involve perception, not thinking.

fields.text: A client reports hearing a voice throughout the day in which the voice says "I am the god of hellfire and you are my servant. I am the god of hellfire and you are under my control." You should assess this client's experience as...
fields.explanation: Hearing a voice that is not present in reality is an hallucination. It is not a delusion. A delusion is a false belief, not a false sensory experience. C is incorrect because it is not an illusion which refers to a distortion of a sensory experience that is based on a reality stimulation. D is incorrect because it is not an idea of reference which, like a delusion, is a thought, not a perception. See the glossary in the Diagnostic Manual of Mental Disorders for more information.

fields.text: Linda, age 4, appears depressed and passive. She tends to isolate herself when peers are around but becomes clingy with adults, sometimes indiscriminately attached. Your assessment should recognize that Linda has most likely been...
fields.explanation: Note the words "most likely" in the question. These are the classic symptoms of neglect, characterized by the reactive attachment disorder of childhood. Physical or sexual abuse can produce these symptoms, but are more likely to lead to anxiety and acting out. Exposure to lead (D) is more likely to cause cognitive deficits.

fields.text: If a person has having healthy object relations that person...
fields.explanation: Flexibility in relationships is the key to healthy object relations, whether or not a person has insight into their unconscious (A). C is false because it refers to the ego function of impulse control, not object relations. D is false because healthy object relations is a matter of the quality, not quantity, of one's social relationships. Be sure that you didn't miss this one simply because it is the fourth question in a row where B was the correct answer. The pattern of letters that indicate correct answers is entirely random. Each question should be taken on its own.

fields.text: Your client, Jonathan W, describes an experience in which he was driving down the freeway and felt "as if I was sitting next to myself in the car." He is frightened by the experience and asks you to explain what it represents. Jonathan is probably...
fields.explanation: Note the word "probably" (i.e. statistically most likely) in the question. This question describes a depersonalization experience. Seventy percent of all individuals have experienced depersonalization at some time in their lives, usually in adolescence or young adulthood. This is not a psychotic symptom (B). Note the words "as if“ in the stem. If this were an hallucination or delusion (a true psychotic symptom), that "as if“ quality would not be there. C is false because "demented" refers to a deficit in cognitive functioning. D is false because confabulation refers to fabricating information to compensate for cognitive dysfunction. See the Glossary in the Diagnostic Manual of Mental Disorders for more information.

fields.text: Your client is the mother of three children who tells you that she wants to teach her children to do their chores. She says that she wants the learning to be stable and long lasting. To accomplish this, you should advise her to reward the child for desirable behavior....
fields.explanation: Intermittent reinforcement, the pattern described in D, has been empirically demonstrated to cause the most stable and long lasting behavior change. A will lead to more rapid extinction of the learned behavior whenever the reward regimen is terminated. B will lead to desirable behavior every fifth time chores are at issue, with a slacking off in between. C (interval reinforcement) weakens the connection between the reward and the desired behavior.

fields.text: You are providing psychotherapy services to clients of all ages who present with a variety of mood disturbances. During the middle phase of therapy you should generally consider using strategies to deal with....
fields.explanation: Motivation wanes during the middle phase as the client retreats to a flight into health, other resistance arise, and the support of the therapeutic context eases the anxiety that motivated change in the first place. B and C are more likely to be issues in the initial phase of therapy. D, goal attainment scaling, can arise during treatment planning but it is too narrow, too specific an issue, when compared to the broader, more significant issue of enhancing motivation. Therefore, it doesn’t require a “strategy.”

fields.text: Your work with depressed clients at a community mental health clinic focuses on reducing depressive symptoms, increasing activity levels, building self-esteem, and strengthening social support networks. You should expect that the phase of psychotherapy that is most likely to precipitate a crisis is...
fields.explanation: Note the words "most likely" in the question. Termination can frustrate a client's sense of dependency on the therapist and on the therapeutic context. It is often associated with a sense of rejection. Crises can arise at any other time during therapy, but they are most directly and most likely precipitated by termination. These statements would be true for depressed clients and other clients as well.

fields.text: You are working with a caseload of deeply depressed clients at a community mental health clinic. You should first use techniques designed to bring about psychotherapeutic change in which phase of psychotherapy?
fields.explanation: All aspects of treatment should be therapeutic. This question only asks about when therapeutic change can begin to happen. It is not asking when therapeutic change is most likely, or most significant. Although individualized intervention strategies are usually implemented following the development of a treatment plan, techniques involved in the development of a therapeutic relationship and the provision of support are a form of generalized treatment applicable to almost all clients during the engagement phase.

fields.text: A client seeks therapy because he wants to stop a pattern of failed relationships. In the first few sessions he shares long stories about loosely related events over the course of his life. He seems to take pleasure in the sharing. He spends little time examining how he might change. In order to mobilize the client's energy for therapeutic change you should....
fields.explanation: The client's behavior is a common way of manifesting resistance in long term, open ended therapy. The literature on crisis intervention and brief therapy usually notes the importance of specifying a limited time frame (A) in order to mobilize energy for therapeutic change. B through D can also be used to mobilize change, or not, but they are more peripherally related to the issue. C, use of role play, neither mobilizes nor inhibits a client's motivation for change. A is directly related to the issue of mobilizing energy for change.

fields.text: Your client is a twenty-five year old man with paranoid personality traits who sees you as a much more authoritarian and harsh person than you really are. He also describes his mother as authoritarian and harsh. Your assessment should recognize this client’s pattern as any of the following except...
fields.explanation: Notice the word "except" in the question. An illusion is a sensory perceptual distortion, not a distorted belief or assumption. Transference involves displacement, so both A and B are true. If neither the mother nor the therapist are authoritarian and harsh, yet the client perceives both of them that way, this is likely to be a projection (C).

fields.text: A client describes his wife. "Diane is so perceptive. Even when people have trouble saying what they mean, she usually seems to know just how they feel anyway. It's like she comes up with just the right words for them, just what they were trying to say but couldn't. And they'll say "Yeah, that's it exactly." He is describing his wife's quality of
fields.explanation: Accurate empathy is a matter of insightful understanding. That is the quality described here. Unconditional positive regard (A) and genuineness (C) refer to more general qualities of the relationship. Codependency (D) has little to do with the question. Codependency is much more likely to involve dysfunctional communication and projection, not sensitive understanding.

fields.text: When a depressed client expresses severe guilt over having stolen a twenty dollar bill from his brother's wallet, which of the following should be your first course of action?
fields.explanation: A is a poor choice because the client is not struggling with understanding guilt. He is struggling with a problem in his life that he needs to resolve. Note that the question's stem does not say that the client is disabled by guilt, only that his guilt is severe. B is a poor choice because the client needs to self-determine a resolution. C is a poor choice because it potentially derails the client's own process of working through the problem and reaching a personally satisfying resolution. D is the best choice because it gives the client a chance to self-explore and work through his thoughts and feelings to a point of resolution.

fields.text: You are about to initiate treatment with a forty year old client who is ambivalent about seeking psychotherapy but has been pressured to seek help by several family members. You should be sure that your therapist-client contract with this individual....
fields.explanation: A contract should always address mutual role expectations. A is false because a treatment contract does not need to be signed by a third party. C is false because a contract should only address suicidal behavior in those cases where it is an issue. In other words, C might be a correct answer in some cases, but B is the correct answer in all cases. D is incorrect because either party may write the contract, as long as both agree to it.

fields.text: You are taking a Structural Family Therapy approach to a family seeking help for a variety of problems which they describe as “dysfunctional communication.” Assuming that this is, in general, a healthy family you should expect to find an unequal and greater share of power in....
fields.explanation: This question relates to Structural Family Therapy. The coalition of parents should have an unequal and greater share of power, that is, more power than any other combination of individuals in the family. B is false because children, with their relatively less developed ego functions and life experience, should not have power greater than that of the parents. C is false because neither parent should be dominant over the other. D is false because children, with their relatively less developed ego functions and life experience, should not have power equal to that of the parents. Besides, it would be unrealistic to think that children could have power equal to that of their parents. Parents have greater personal and material resources, as well as legal rights within the family.

fields.text: In the context of family treatment the therapist...
fields.explanation: The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that “In the context of couple, family or group treatment, the therapist may not reveal any individual’s R confidences to others in the client unit without the prior written permission of that individual.” A is incorrect because the therapist may only reveal such information with a written consent.
