Even after taking such steps, it is a good idea to ask students to treat the information confidentially just in case they or others recognize a subtle identifying feature that you have overlooked, but the fundamental protection is not the students' confidentiality commitment...it is the steps you take to protect the clients identity. B is incorrect because, even though this is an acceptable approach, the better approach is to avoid using identifying information in the first place, especially because you have no way of assuring that students would actually protect the confidentiality of your client if identifying information was presented to them. C is incorrect because you would have to reveal something about your client's identity in the process of checking to see if any of the students knew the client.

fields.text: In treating a 39 year old man who entered psychotherapy for help with a long standing pattern of self-defeating behavior, emotional lability and a series of unstable relationships with women, the best therapy approach for you to use would be...
fields.explanation: A refers to a behavioral intervention that is used to reduce anxiety in the presence of anxiety arousing stimuli. Most marriage and family therapists would consider it reductionistic (an oversimplification) to simply view this client's problems as anxiety responses to particular stimuli. They involve his sense of identity, self-image, object relations, belief systems, and other issues that are imbued with meaning. B is incorrect because it also refers to another behavioral intervention that is used to reduce anxiety in the presence of anxiety arousing stimuli. D is incorrect because approach would not be change oriented and a short term approach would probably not be sufficient since he presents a complex problem with many facets.

fields.text: Your client is a 44 year old man who sounds like an adolescent when he complains about his parents. He denies any clear abuse or neglect, but states that "they were never there for me," "they just couldn't cut it as parents," and "they had problems." He blames his current problems with underachievement and social relationships on the Way his parents raised him. Your approach to this client should recognize that he...
fields.explanation: According to Erik Erikson, the person of integrity has a profound acceptance of self and others, including one's parents. They look beyond what their parents did and did not do for them and, instead, they look at the ways in which their parents were people "like me." Integrity involves a sense that we each do as well as we possibly can with the resources, life circumstances and historical conditions available to us. B is incorrect because the client needs to develop a better understanding of his perceptions and see what he can learn from them. The approach presented in B would only lead the client to suppress or repress his perceptions and feelings. C is incorrect because, even though it is possible, A is more likely. D is incorrect because it assumes the client's negative view and reinforces it. This approach has been associated with "false memory syndrome." A better approach would be to help the client uncover more specific memories of his experiences with his parents, both positive and negative, not only their mistreatment of him.

fields.text: You are employed by a large public mental health service organization which emphasizes a system of care and service delivery through multidisciplinary teamwork. You are expected to exercise independent judgment with regard to...
fields.explanation: Legal reporting mandates apply to individual practitioners, not usually to agencies. All other response options are incorrect because they are the prerogative of supervisors and managers. The professional marriage and family therapist should, however, have input into developing policies, procedures and assignments.

fields.text: You should use the term "ethnic culture" to refer to the culture of a community of people who have a common identity based on a common...
fields.explanation: Consider, for example, Jews. Not all Jewish people observe the same religion. Some observe no religion at all. Some are Buddhists. Even if a Jewish person were-to accept Christianity he or she would still be recognized as a Jewish Christian. Although Jewish people had a common nationality in Biblical times, they were identified as a people with a common history even before entering their ancient nation. Although members of an ethnic group often have a common political interest, they will often share this political interest with others, and there is often a variety of political interests among members of an ethnic group, especially members of various socioeconomic classes.

fields.text: You are working with a chaotic and dysfunctional family in which an adolescent daughter has begun acting out sexually and engaging in petty theft from her grandparents. You have offered family therapy, based on Social Systems Theory, as a potentially effective treatment approach for the family's problems. You will be intervening to change...
fields.explanation: In family therapy these "sequences of behavior among people" are the family's communications, or family dynamics. The experienced family therapist focuses on changing the family system. A is incorrect because, even when a key individual is the focus of change as in Bowen's approach to family therapy, the individual's change is sought because of its effect on the sequences of behavior between that individual and others in the family. C is incorrect because not all families have two parents, and not all family problems are directly related to the parental coalition. D is incorrect because family therapy focuses on changing the family system, not the individual whom the family has labeled as "the problem."

fields.text: You are working with a chaotic and dysfunctional family in which an adolescent daughter has begun acting out sexually and engaging in petty theft from her parents. You have offered family therapy as a potentially effective treatment approach for the family's problems. You may foster the development of integration in this family system through...
fields.explanation: Integration means action by the family system to bring about harmonious interaction of component members in service of the family's goals. People in any kind of group will work toward harmonious interaction to the extent that they become aware of their common goals and mutual needs. A is incorrect because, even though it refers to a desirable quality in family life, the focus on differences is not as directly related to integration as a focus on commonalities. B is incorrect because all systems have roles and norms, whether or not they are well integrated. D is incorrect because all stable systems, including well integrated systems, have dominance hierarchies. In a well integrated family system the dominance hierarchy is one that will likely feel acceptable and even desirable to the family members.

fields.text: Your client is a young Latina professional woman who needs help developing self- esteem, learning self-assertion skills, and developing a more clear self-concept. She would most benefit from a group where which of the following characteristics are found?
fields.explanation: Positive change in group members is promoted in psychotherapy groups and other groups that favor experimentation and flexibility. A is incorrect because positive change is fostered in groups that are group centered with an open system of communication, rather than in groups that are leader centered. B is incorrect because an open airing of conflict is needed for a group to resolve conflicts, develop mutually acceptable resolutions, and develop cohesiveness. Open airing of conflict would also give your client opportunities to learn and practice assertion skills. D is incorrect because the presence or absence of co-therapists has little bearing on the objectives that may be achieved through group therapy.

fields.text: In reviewing the previous clinical records of African American clients, you should recognize that persons of this ethic culture tend to be overdiagnosed as having...
fields.explanation: This finding has been established in empirical research on the misdiagnosis of clients with "major depression with psychotic features." The misdiagnosis also occurs with clients of other ethnicities, but at a somewhat higher rate among African American clients.

fields.text: If your client is too young to give informed consent you...
fields.explanation: This principle is stated in the AAMFT Code of Ethics. A is incorrect because ethical practice requires that informed consent be provided from either the client or a legally authorized person. B is incorrect because a supervisor has no authority to speak on behalf of a client. D is incorrect because a child's parents may not be the ones legally authorized to give consent. For example, in some cases of abuse, neglect or abandonment the court may assume authority to authorize a child's services "in loco parentis." C is a better answer than D because it is more inclusive.

fields.text: You have received a referral of a new client who presents with delusional jealousy and occasional auditory hallucinations in which he hears the word "hatred" repeated over and over again. Your approach to this client should recognize that he is...
fields.explanation: Note the words "Your client is" (a definitive statement) in the question. Delusions and hallucinations are psychotic symptoms. A is incorrect because this client's psychotic symptoms may be due to a serious long term mental disorder such as schizophrenia, but they might also be having these symptoms because of intoxication, abuse, a brief psychosis, or a medical condition. The latter conditions lead to symptom remission with time and/or treatment. B is incorrect because, although the client may be abusing drugs, it is too conclusive a statement to say that the client is abusing drugs. You don't have enough information to know that. D is incorrect because you have enough information to know that the individual is acutely psychotic but much more information would be needed in order to know that the psychosis was due to schizophrenia.

fields.text: Which of the following approaches to the therapist-client relationship would you expect from a middle age African American client with healthy object relations?
fields.explanation: We need to be dependent about some issues in our lives, and independent about others. When we need to be dependent, we should be able to place that dependency in people who are trustworthy and capable, not just anybody. A and B are incorrect because they are too one sided. C is incorrect because a person with healthy object relations would be open to accepting dependency from others when appropriate, but would not invite it whenever possible.

fields.text: You are the therapist for a psychotherapy group designed to help individuals with
fields.explanation: The primary task of group psychotherapy is to accomplish personal change and growth through honest self-exploration. Trying to project any particular image of oneself to other members, and trying to win others.' approval will not accomplish this. A is incorrect because this client may be engaging in these behaviors primarily in relation to the other group members, not because of his relationship with the therapist. B is incorrect because these behaviors might be present only in this kind of group situation. Characterological manipulation would be persistent and pervasive, but there is no indication that this is the case for this client. D is incorrect because C is correct, and D presents an opposite statement.

fields.text: You are the therapist of a client who is about to sell her car to a naive buyer at twice the true market value. In order to accomplish this she has set him up by failing to tell him about a serious hidden defect that reduces gas mileage by half. You should...
fields.explanation: A is incorrect because it would be a violation of confidentiality. The destructive potential of the client's behavior is not sufficient to warrant a Tarrasoff warning. B is incorrect for the same reason that A is incorrect and because the client will likely hold you responsible for the outcome of having followed your advice. D is also incorrect because the client will likely hold you responsible for the outcome of having followed your advice. C is correct because the client needs to know that her behavior is manipulative and deceptive, and learn about herself to the extent that this issue has a bearing on the goals and purpose of your therapeutic contract.

fields.text: You would be most likely to use the empty chair technique for purposes of self- exploration when practicing which of the following approaches to therapy?
fields.explanation: A is incorrect because behavior modification does not use techniques for this kind of self-exploration. B and C are incorrect because, even though therapists using these approaches might occasionally use the empty chair technique, the technique was developed by and is primarily associated with Gestalt Therapy. D therefore, is the best choice.

fields.text: Which of the following should you consider to be an example of making a purposeful use of self in a psychotherapy relationship?
fields.explanation: Empathic listening involves using one's imagination to experience the client's thoughts and feelings as if they were one's own. A, B and D incorrect because they do not rely as much on the clinician's personal resources. A, B, and D could conceivably be done by a well-programmed computer, but a person's imagination and sensitive listening are required for truly empathic listening.

fields.text: Your client, an insecure 29 year old businessman, is anxious about a major sales presentation he needs to make in two weeks. He wants to reduce his anxiety level prior to making the presentation. He states that he is not interested in working on long term personality change. Your best therapeutic approach would focus on...
fields.explanation: This approach is indicated by the fact that you have two weeks to accomplish the requested objective and by the fact that the client is not interested in fundamental personality change. A and B are incorrect because these treatment strategies are geared to long term personality change and would not likely achieve any significant change within two weeks. C is incorrect because it probably wouldn't be helpful.

fields.text: You are about to initiate family therapy with the Andersons who have sought your help in resolving a long standing family conflict. Mrs. Anderson and her daughter have been arguing to allow her mother to come live with the family in their downstairs "in-law apartment." Mr. Anderson and his daughter from a prior marriage have been arguing to preserve the Sin-law apartment" for one of the daughters. Each of the daughters argue to have the apartment if, in fact, the grandmother is not allowed to move in. In your approach to this case you should...
fields.explanation: Although a family therapist strives to focus on the family as a whole and be impartial to each of its members, identifications, biases and countertransferences are inevitable from time to time. In order to maintain credibility and a sense of genuineness in the therapeutic relationship, this should be shared with the clients. This is effective modeling and provides "grist for the mill" when examining behavior sequences with the family. A is incorrect because the therapist's human qualities inevitably lead to identification, bias and countertransferences at times, especially in contentious situations such as this one. C is incorrect because nonverbal cues will inevitably reveal the experience of taking sides. By failing to acknowledge what is already revealed anyway, the therapist loses credibility and models dysfunctional communication. D is incorrect because the family therapist needs to focus on the family system, and avoid the temptation to rescue an individual.

fields.text: Your client characteristically uses the following four defense mechanisms. Which of these should you work toward replacing with more effective defenses, due to the fact that it is most primitive?
fields.explanation: A primitive defense mechanism is one that leads to the greatest distortion of reality, is available at a very young age, and is relatively dysfunctional, even when it is effective in reducing immediate anxiety. Denial fails to acknowledge reality, and it is available even in infancy as when a baby closes his eyes or turns his head away from something he doesn't want to acknowledge. A is incorrect because sublimation is one of the most advanced defense mechanisms. By definition it effectively leads to adaptation. C and D are incorrect because these defenses are not available at a young age. They require verbal and intellectual skills that are not available in infancy. They are also somewhat more accessible to influence through rational discussion than is denial.

fields.text: You are working with a young woman who needs help in resolving a sense of direction in life. She needs to make a major career choice prior to a graduate school application deadline that is coming up in several months. According to Humanistic Existential Psychotherapy approaches you should relate to your client in an accepting manner because a therapist's acceptance promotes...
fields.explanation: Acceptance by the therapist promotes the client's acceptance of self. This leads to a sense of integrity or wholeness, which makes it possible for the client to know what he or she most needs. A is incorrect because acceptance can include acknowledging one's negative aspects or limitations. This does not always directly contribute to self-esteem. C is incorrect because the therapist's influence is not the major focus of change in Client Centered Therapy, the approach most likely serving as a frame of reference for this question. D is incorrect because not all clients are seeking to enhance their sense of altruism. This treatment approach takes no moralistic stand on whether or not a client should become more altruistic, only that the client become more of whatever is the true self.

fields.text: In reviewing studies that control for socioeconomic status, you should expect to find that the true prevalence of mental disorders among African Americans as compared to Americans of European descent will be...
fields.explanation: Prevalence of mental disorders is about the same when African Americans are compared to Americans of European descent. Socioeconomic status has a greater association with prevalence than does ethnicity.

fields.text: You have four clients, each presenting with pessimistic anticipation, autonomic hyperactivity, emotional lability, insomnia, and occasional fleeting hallucinations. Which of these four clients should you expect to have the best prognosis?
fields.explanation: Good prognostic signs include sudden onset, onset triggered by a stressor, recent onset, and high premorbid functioning. Poor prognostic signs include insidious onset, onset in the absence of a stressor, and chronic history. If the symptoms are ego syntonic motivation to change will be minimal or absent. If the symptoms are a manifestation of a personality disorder (the conditions described in answer C) the prognosis will also be poor. Note that, among other things, A is the pattern found in an adjustment disorder, B is the pattern found in schizophrenia, C is the pattern found in personality disorder, and D is also commonly found in personality disorder and chemical dependency. *

fields.text: You rent office space from a psychologist colleague, someone whose Work you hold in high esteem. Under California law, which of the following principles should you not use as an aspect of your rental agreement?
fields.explanation: No compensation, whether monetary or otherwise, may be paid for the referral of professional clients. A and B are incorrect because, even though this kind of bartering agreement would be unprofessional conduct in a therapist/ client relationship, bartering is not prohibited as an aspect of a rental agreement. The therapist would have to be careful to assure that neither the rental agreement nor the bartering influences any professional collegial relationship with the psychologist. C is incorrect because there is no prohibition against basing rental payments on a proportion of gross income.

fields.text: Your client is troubled by both a deep depression as well as distressing hallucinations that impair psychosocial functioning. Both the mood symptoms and the psychotic symptoms are very prominent and both first appeared at about the same time. Your diagnostic formulation should recognize that this client's diagnosis is probably...
fields.explanation: A is incorrect. A would be correct if the mood symptoms were more prominent and occurred first. C is incorrect. C would be correct if the psychotic symptoms were characteristic of schizophrenia, and if the psychotic symptoms were more prominent and occurred first. D is incorrect because psychotic symptoms are not a defining feature of the schizotypal personality disorder.

fields.text: In some cultures the open expression of emotional distress, especially by persons in subservient positions, may be socially or politically difficult, as this could imply dissatisfaction with the status quo. In some Asian cultures these emotions find alternative means of expression such as...
fields.explanation: Although repressed or suppressed distress might become manifest in either of these ways, cultural norms in some Asian cultures favor expression through somatization or dissociation. A is incorrect because anxiety is a direct expression of emotional distress, not an alternative means of expression. It is also incorrect because anger could imply dissatisfaction with the status quo, rather than mask one's dissatisfaction. B is incorrect because acting out would also directly reveal one's dissatisfaction, and it is not particularly associated with norms of Asian cultures. D is incorrect because intellectualization or rationalization are defense mechanisms which tend to be favored by people of higher intelligence or education across cultures. They are not particularly associated with norms of Asian cultures. Also, people of average intelligence or lower educational attainment in Asian cultures would be less likely to use these defenses, as would be true for similar individuals in other cultures.

fields.text: Unprofessional conduct is defined in California law as including all of the following except one. Which one?
fields.explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. You are permitted to advertise your services, including your availability for referrals, as long as the advertising is neither false nor misleading. A, C and D are all specifically prohibited as unprofessional conduct under California state law. 115'. The correct answer is MISSING. disturbed social relatedness are not characteristic of mentally retarded children. C is incorrect because, even though the lack of social relatedness may be found in autism, normal speech would not be expected and other characteristic symptoms of autism are not described here.  D is incorrect because, even though a simple adjustment problem would involve sadness or anxiety after suffering such a loss and displacement, after five months most children probably would have made a better social adjustment than the one described here.

fields.text: Johnny is a 4 year old boy who has been in a nurturing foster placement for 5 months. He was placed in the home after his mother abandoned the family and his alcoholic father felt that he was unable to care for the children. Johnny lacks spontaneity and fails to respond to his caretakers' efforts to reach out to him and offer affection. Speech is normal but Johnny is usually very quiet. He occasionally plays with toys or watches television, but never in concert with another person. Your assessment should recognize that Johnny probably...
fields.explanation: MISSING

fields.text: Several of your clients are children who do not meet the criteria for any DSM diagnosis, but express distress when separation from major attachment figures is anticipated. They are reluctant to be alone without their major attachment figures, and refuse to go to sleep without being near a major attachment figure. Such behavior is most likely to be developmentally appropriate for a child in which of the following age ranges?
fields.explanation: Separation anxiety usually first appears during the latter months of a child's first year and is developmentally characteristic of young toddlers. A is incorrect because such young infants do not experience separation anxiety. C and D are incorrect because separation anxiety at these ages would indicate a problem, not a developmentally appropriate experience.

fields.text: Ever since adolescence your 38 year old client has been excessively suspicious about persecution in most social situations. He tends to suspect, without sufficient basis, that others are exploiting, harming, or deceiving him, and is preoccupied with unjustified doubts about the loyalty or trustworthiness of friends and associates. These features are best described as...
fields.explanation: B is incorrect because, although some delusions are paranoid delusions, not all paranoia is delusional. This client's description says nothing about a firmly held, false paranoid belief that almost nobody else believes. These are the qualities that distinguish paranoid delusions from the more common paranoid personality trait. C is incorrect because hallucinations are sensory experiences without a corresponding external stimulus. Paranoia, on the other hand, is usually a matter of what a person thinks or believes, not what they experience in a sensory way. D is incorrect I because, even though paranoia usually causes stress, it is not necessarily caused by stress. For example, it may be caused by long standing personality patterns, substance use, or organic causes, even in the absence of stress. A is correct because problematic, persistent and pervasive personality tendencies are called personality traits.

fields.text: Your colleague is a Marriage and Family Therapist with whom you have collaborated on many cases. The two of you have also seen one another socially and at community events. When this colleague refers a client to you, how are you permitted to reward the colleague for the referral? .
fields.explanation: It is unethical and unprofessional conduct to provide anything of material value in exchange for receiving a referral. You are free to refer a client to the colleague at some time in the future, but A is incorrect because that referral may not be "in exchange" for the referral that you received. Referrals should be based solely on what is in the best interest of the client.

fields.text: You are working with a family in which the children are raised with overpermissiveness and indulgence. Sometimes the parents' a approach to the children appears to be the result of their own self-involvement, and sometimes it reflects a firm but mistaken belief that permissiveness and indulgence lead to healthy psychosocial development. If the parents persist in this parenting style, you should expect that their children will be prone to develop all of the following qualities except...
fields.explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. Unlike rejected children who have difficulty entering into interpersonal relationships, overindulged children enter readily into relationships. However, when they do their behavior tends to be exploitive, antisocial and aggressive.

fields.text: You are leading a bereavement support group involving nine individuals who are grieving the death of a spouse. Both men and women are among the group members. Some of them attend church, and some do not. You are most likely to find that the person's loss will have led to depression in which of your group's members?
fields.explanation: Church or synagogue attendance has been found to mitigate against depression upon death of a spouse. Also, men are more prone than women to experience depression upon death of a spouse. It has been hypothesized that this effect is due to either women's greater access to social supports or men's socialized reluctance to use their social supports effectively due to suppressed emotion and a reluctance to speak openly of problems and vulnerabilities.

fields.text: You are treating a seventeen year old boy who is generally anxious and insecure. He now tells you that he is worried about a forthcoming algebra examination. In order to effectively express support you should say...
fields.explanation: This implies acceptance of the exam outcome, whatever it might be. B and D are incorrect because they anticipate a good result on the exam, but there is no way of knowing what the result will be. C is incorrect because it minimizes the importance of the examination, even though the exam might be important to the client. Also, C would deprive the client of a sense of pride if he or she were to do well on the exam.

fields.text: You have been treating a sixty year old woman with a schizotypal personality disorder. After seeing you for several months the client requests to see her clinical record. You should limit her access...
fields.explanation: This is both a legal and ethical issue. Clients have a legal right to access the information in their clinical records. B is incorrect because the Code of Ethics allows you to limit access for the reasons listed in answer A. C is incorrect because many clients would be able to know their diagnosis without serious harm. D is incorrect because the therapist's fantasies shouldn't be in a clinical record. However, even if they were, they would only be off limits if they met the kind of circumstances specified in answer A.

fields.text: You are working with the forty year old husband of a rape victim. The couple has been married for fifteen years. Her husband clearly wants to be helpful to his wife. Which of the following should you encourage from the husband?
fields.explanation: Empathic listening will allow the traumatized spouse to work through the experience at her own pace and without the pressure of external expectations. A and B are often associated with increased stress for the traumatized spouse. C is not effective because it gives a false reassurance.

fields.text: Your new client is a forty-five year old Asian woman who clearly presents with low self-esteem and a sense of worthlessness, but you have not yet developed a differential diagnosis. If these symptoms are core features of this woman's mental disorder, you are most likely to find that her diagnosis is...
fields.explanation: Low self-esteem and a sense of worthlessness are associated with depression. Depression is the core feature of a dysthymic disorder and these two symptoms are among the defining criteria of this disorder. Although low self- esteem and a sense of worthlessness might also be associated with any of the other disorders listed, especially schizophrenia, they are associated features, not core or defining features, of these other diagnoses. B, therefore, is the best answer.

fields.text: In conducting an assessment and developing a diagnostic formulation, which of the following should you consider to be vegetative signs of depression?
fields.explanation: Vegetative signs of depression are the physical, as opposed to psychological, signs. All symptoms listed in C are physical. The other response options contain psychological signs such as recurrent thoughts about death or feelings of worthlessness.

fields.text: You are meeting with a consultant to determine the appropriate intervention methodology in a complex case. Once the client has given you consent to release information to the consultant you may...
fields.explanation: The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "Information may be shared only to the extent necessary to achieve the purposes of the consultation." A is incorrect because the consultant might request information out of curiosity that is not relevant to achieving the purposes of the consultation. It is your responsibility to protect the client's confidentiality, and you may not simply rely on the consultant's discretion in this matter. B is incorrect because the client might be willing for you to release more information than is necessary. You would still have an ethical responsibility to present information only as necessary to achieve the consultation purpose. C is incorrect because you may reveal such private information if the client has given consent and if it is relevant to achieving the purpose of the consultation.

fields.text: In conducting developmental assessments, which psychosocial conflict should you expect to be preeminent just before the conflict between intimacy and a sense of isolation from others becomes preeminent?
fields.explanation: Intimacy vs. isolation is the stage of young adulthood. It follows identity vs. identity diffusion which is the primary conflict of adolescence.

fields.text: Before assigning a "not otherwise specified" diagnosis to a client, you must first determine that...
fields.explanation: By definition, a mental disorder is a clinically significant syndrome involving distress or impaired social functioning. These qualities must be present before assigning any DSM diagnosis to a client, including the NOS diagnoses. A and B are incorrect because these response options refer to symptoms of certain NOS diagnoses, but they do not apply to all NOS diagnoses. C is incorrect because many mental disorders, and therefore many NOS diagnoses, have a physical or cognitive etiology, not psychodynamic.

fields.text: You have published an article based on your work with a sample of your clients. In the article you are careful to state the limitations of the study, but a colleague has overlooked those cautions and has written articles in your profession's newsletters which draw false positive conclusions regarding the effectiveness of your work.
fields.explanation: The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "Marriage and family therapists make efforts to prevent the distortion or misuse of their clinical and research findings." The actions described in answer B fulfill this ethical standard. A is incorrect because it is insufficient to disclaim ownership of the misinterpretation. The ethical standard calls on you "to prevent the distortion or misuse" of your information. C is incorrect because this ethical responsibility is established in the code of ethics. The responsibility to correct the misinformation does not depend on whether or not you have caused or contributed to it. D is incorrect because there is a way in which just about anything is true. Presumably your original report presented what you have established to be true. Answer D suggests an effort to take advantage of your colleagues error to promote your own self interest.

fields.text: The California Business and Professions Code states that the license of a Licensed Marriage and Family Therapist can be revoked or suspended if the MFT...
fields.explanation: This requirement is set forth in Business and Professions Code Sec. 4982 regarding unprofessional conduct. A is incorrect because substance use is not prohibited per se. It is prohibited if the substance is used to the extent, or in a manner, as to be dangerous or injurious to the MFT or to any other person, or if it impairs the ability of the MFT to safely conduct the practice of marriage and family therapy. B is incorrect because the use of illegal substances is prohibited by other laws, but the Business and Professions Code only addresses this issue to the extent that it is relevant to the MFT's professional practice, as just described. C is incorrect because the law does not reference diagnostic criteria. A person might meet the criteria for alcohol abuse, for example, in a way that does not create a significant danger to clients or to the public.

fields.text: Your client is a manipulative young man who repeatedly refers to you as "my psychologist." Although you have clearly told the client that you are marriage and family therapist, not a psychologist, the client continues to refer to you as a psychologist. You should... L
fields.explanation: Under California law it is unprofessional conduct to MISSING 132'. The correct answer is MISSING. 133'. The correct answer is MISSING. 134'. The correct answer is MISSING. 135'. The correct answer is MISSING. 136'. The correct answer is MISSING. 137'. The correct answer is MISSING. 138'. The correct answer is MISSING. incorrect because the Tarasoff obligation applies whether or not the client's behavior would constitute a felony. Therefore A is true but D is a better answer because it is more inclusive and reflects the actual legal obligation as stated in the judicial decision. B is incorrect because the Tarasoff decision does not apply to any serious harm. It only applies to a serious danger of violence. C is incorrect because the decision applies to serious violence rather than just any serious harm, and because the therapist has no obligation to inform the intended victim when the client is deemed to no longer pose a danger.

fields.text: A marriage and family therapy colleague at a community mental health clinic is having a sexual relationship with a supervisee. Your response should recognize that your colleague should...
fields.explanation: MISSING

fields.text: Federal HIPAA legislation allows a marriage and family therapist to deny a client's access to "psychotherapy notes." "Psychotherapy notes" refers to...
fields.explanation: MISSING

fields.text: Under California's Patient Access to Records Act a marriage and family therapist...
fields.explanation: MISSING

fields.text: Your client is a fifty year old man with a histrionic personality disorder who sought your help in dealing with work related stress. Whenever your client is harassed at work by his boss, he comes home and initiates arguments with his wife. This client is using the defense mechanism of...
fields.explanation: MISSING

fields.text: A marriage and family therapist must provide a minor with access to health care records...
fields.explanation: MISSING

fields.text: Under the Elder and Dependent Adult Reporting Act, a report must be made if an elder's needs are not being met
fields.explanation: MISSING

fields.text: By Virtue of the Tarasoff decision a marriage and family therapist must...
fields.explanation: MISSING

fields.text: Your anxious client is scheduled for an amputation of the left leg in three days. You can help your client reduce the stress resulting from her surgery by.
fields.explanation: Anticipatory guidance is widely recognized as an effective means of reducing stress reactions to predictable stressors. A is incorrect because you cannot effectively and significantly build a person's self-esteem in three days. C is incorrect because this would be false assurance. You don't really know if the person will be able to handle the stress effectively. D is incorrect because, even though some psychological conditions might warrant postponement of surgery, simple anxiety is not sufficient cause. Most everyone is anxious in anticipation of surgery.

fields.text: When working with clients in a stress reduction clinic, you should help your clients understand that all of the following have been found to reduce the level of stress experienced by a person except for the person's...
fields.explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. Level of education doesn't help a person manage stress. B is incorrect because our sense of adequacy and worthiness lead to confidence and the ability to cope with stress. C is incorrect because the very purpose of ego defenses is to manage anxiety, including the anxiety that results from stress. D is incorrect because understanding the nature of a stressful situation gives a person a sense of control, a "cognitive grasp" as it is referred to in the crisis intervention literature.

fields.text: Section 5150 of the Welfare and Institutions Code...
fields.explanation: The law states that "When any person, as a result of mental disorder, is a danger to others, or to himself or herself, or gravely disabled, a peace officer, member of the attending staff, as defined by regulation, of an evaluation facility designated by the county, designated members of a mobile crisis team provided by Section 5651.7, or other professional person designated by the county may, upon probable cause, take, or cause to be taken, the person into custody and place him or her in a facility designated by the county and approved by the State Department of Mental Health as a facility for 72-hour treatment and evaluation." A is incorrect because the law does not authorize any marriage and family therapist to involuntarily hold a person. The MFT must be specially designated, for example by virtue of being on the staff of a mobile crisis team. C is incorrect because any peace officer may involuntarily hold an individual under this law if the peace officer believes the person to be a danger due to a mental disorder. The assumption regarding the mental disorder does not need to be confirmed by a mental health professional. D is incorrect because only certain designated mental health professionals may hold a person involuntarily, regardless of the opinion of a peace officer.

fields.text: Your client has recently experienced a severe trauma. She was the victim of an attempted rape but was saved when a police car happened to drive by the scene by chance. The perpetrator fled but your client was severely distressed by the assault. Your therapeutic approach should include all of the following elements except...
fields.explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. While you should accept the client's expressions of anger and even retribution if that's what the client is thinking and feeling, you should not encourage such expression. B is incorrect. You should be supportive rather than confrontive. C is incorrect. You should allow the client to repeatedly talk about the trauma. This can be used as the basis for developing a sense of understanding and restoring a sense of control. D is incorrect. This intervention can serve to protect the client's health and help her maintain the stamina needed for effective therapeutic engagement.

fields.text: Your clinical assessments and treatment plans should recognize that one of the following emotions has been found to be especially highly conditionable, that is, readily transferred to previously neutral stimuli. Which one?
fields.explanation: Note the word "especially" in the question. Fear and anxiety are exceptionally subject to conditioning and to being transferred (generalized) to previously neutral stimuli.

fields.text: Your clients, a married couple, came to therapy claiming that "we need to improve our communication." Early assessment revealed a problem of recurrent violent outbursts on the part of both partners. By the fourth month the couple has shown some improvement but violent outbursts continue and are now described as "open expressions of anger." Suddenly both partners say that they have achieved their goal in therapy and want to terminate. You should take this to mean that your clients are experiencing...
fields.explanation: Resistance and flight into health often occur in the middle phase of therapy. It is a way of avoiding the increasingly difficult issues that arise after early defenses are worked through. A is incorrect because the request to terminate came suddenly and without a substantial resolution of the clients' major problem. C is incorrect because no specific evidence of this is provided in the vignette. D is incorrect because countertransference refers to the therapist's thought, feelings and/or behavior, not the client's.

fields.text: You have been asked to develop diagnostic formulations of family dynamics as a consultant to a group of pediatricians. Among other issues they have asked you to identify patterns of enmeshment or disengagement. These are problems of family system...
fields.explanation: Enmeshment and disengagement are problems of resonance. In enmeshment family members are much too responsive to one another's thoughts, feelings and actions. They resonate or react to the slightest cue, thereby interfering with the autonomy of individual family members. In disengagement there is very little resonance to one another, even when important issues are raised by a family member. A is incorrect because family systems are not designed. They arise and grow through natural development, not intentional planning. B is incorrect because a family's resonance relates to any issue in family life, not just authority issues. D is incorrect because enmeshment and disengagement are more directly related to family process or dynamics rather than structure.

fields.text: Your client has been depressed over a series of what she calls "failed relationships" in which she has been subject to exploitation and scapegoating. Your client's goal is to reduce depression and improve her sense of confidence. You should recommend that the treatment plan include, as appropriate objectives, any of the following except...
fields.explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. Free floating anxiety is not directly related to depression, self-doubt or vulnerability to exploitation by others. In any case, it is not as directly related as are the other three qualities listed: self- assertion skills, self-esteem and self-acceptance.

fields.text: Your depressed client has threatened suicide and claims that she intends to take an overdose of sleeping pills, prescribed by her internist, sometime within the next few days. She has made such threats before on three occasions over the past two years. She has made one ineffective suicide attempt which you consider to have been an attempt to gain attention and dependency. Which of the following should be your first course of action?
fields.explanation: The client's threat should be taken seriously, especially because she is depressed, has a specific plan, has the means to carry it out, and expresses an immediate intention to act within the next few days. B is incorrect because it does not address the risk. C is incorrect because it does not address the risk sufficiently. Under these circumstances even three or four outpatient sessions per week might not provide sufficient monitoring. D is incorrect because an abrupt termination would constitute client abandonment and because you should be able to manage a suicide risk, in collaboration with others such as the psychiatrist.

fields.text: You suggest termination to a client with whom you've been working for 9 months because she has substantially reached her primary goals and objectives. You should expect that her termination will be least likely to give rise to which of the following conditions?
fields.explanation: There is no need to renegotiate the treatment plan if primary goals and objectives have been achieved. If the client seeks to renegotiate at this point, it is probably a regression and will serve as an opportunity to learn about how the client handles loss. Termination is a loss and, if sufficient time is allotted to work it through, clients can learn skills in coping with loss during the termination process (A). Also, client regression often occurs at termination as a way of trying to reverse the decision and maintain the relationship (B). Finally, if a client takes the termination as a rejection, the client is apt to find ways to reject the therapist in return, perhaps by devaluing the therapist and expressing hostility (C). A

fields.text: You are working with a bereavement support group. The members are free of diagnosable mental disorders but could benefit from supportive services. Which of the following symptoms would you not expect to find among these clients who are experiencing normal bereavement?
fields.explanation: A is incorrect because it is not unusual for survivors to hear the voice or sense the presence of the deceased. B is incorrect because depression is perhaps the most characteristic symptom of bereavement. D is incorrect because agitation often expresses the survivor's anxiety and attempts to create distractions from his or her depressing thoughts. C may occur in bereavement, but it is not as characteristic as are the other symptoms listed. Impaired immediate recall is a sign of organic mental disorder.

fields.text: You are working with a thirty-two year old male, African American client with paranoid schizophrenia. You should consider which of the following to be the least helpful intervention for this client if he has recently become depressed after being evicted from his apartment for loud outbursts in the middle of the night?
fields.explanation: Note the words "least helpful" in the question. A Interpretive psychotherapy is usually to be avoided in work with clients who have schizophrenia. The abstract nature of interpretive inferences are confusing to the thought disordered client. Confronting defenses may also be unnecessarily threatening, especially to a client who is paranoid. Case management is needed to provide social support and assistance in obtaining resources and an alternative living arrangement (A). Medications may be needed to restore impulse control and control the symptoms that likely led to the late night outbursts (B). Psychosocial rehabilitation may also be needed to learn better ways of coping with stresses that may have led to the outbursts (D). Also, this client may need help in an apartment search and in negotiating relationships with a new landlord and neighbors.

fields.text: Your new client states that he has sought psychotherapy because he strives for a greater capacity for intimacy. In the course of your work with this client, which of the following developmental issues should you address first?
fields.explanation: The stage of intimacy vs. isolation immediately follows the stage of identity vs. identity diffusion or role diffusion. Erikson explains that in order to feel the security needed to risk one's identity by fusing it with that of another person, one must first feel secure in one's own identity. B is incorrect because the developmental issue of generativity vs. stagnation follows intimacy vs. isolation. Generativity becomes possible once we have learned to enter into the intimate relationships that make it possible to generate families, projects and careers. C is incorrect because the question is based on an Eriksonian conceptual framework. Erikson does not focus on such Freudian psychosexual issues as the Oedipal conflict. D is incorrect because Erikson's theory is not a theory of psychotherapy. He does not prescribe the method for achieving growth and development. Instead, he focuses on describing the sequence of issues that must be addressed as a person grows and develops.

fields.text: Your client is a forty-five year old business manager who would like to develop a greater capacity for self-assertive behavior in social relationships. In order to monitor the clients eventual progress you should first establish a baseline by measuring which of the following?
fields.explanation: Frequency refers to how often the behavior occurs. Magnitude refers to the strength or intensity of the behavior. Duration refers to how long the behavior lasts when it does occur. B is incorrect because it ignores duration. Magnitude and intensity mean essentially the same thing. C is incorrect because motivation, capacity and situation opportunities are three important aspects of all clinical assessments, but they are not particularly relevant to establishing a behavioral baseline. These concepts are too abstract to serve as a basis for setting a behavioral baseline. D is incorrect because it only refers to frequency, not magnitude and duration.

fields.text: In the course of developing greater self-assertive skills with your forty-five year old client, you will be using behavioral rehearsal. Your approach should involve all of the following techniques except...
fields.explanation: Behavioral rehearsal is similar to role playing. First the therapist describes or demonstrates the desired behavior. Then the client practices what has been taught. Then the client is provided with feedback and reward for desired behaviors. Extinction may occur, as with any learned behavior, but it is not part of the behavioral rehearsal procedure.

fields.text: You are using a Cognitive Behavioral approach to therapy in which you and the client will be working to modify dysfunctional automatic thoughts. Your work will involve...
fields.explanation: The same principles of both operant and respondent learning apply to thoughts as they do to behavior. A is incorrect because psychoactive medications may alter one's thoughts, but they are not usually directly used as part of the cognitive therapy process. C is incorrect because, although operant conditioning may be used, it is only one of many techniques. B is a better answer because it is more inclusive. D is incorrect because, although reward is used in cognitive behavioral therapy, punishment (or aversive stimuli) may be used as well.

fields.text: A new client has requested that you use the technique of flooding in his treatment. He explains that he has a friend whose therapist has used this technique very successfully. You should explain to the client that flooding may or may not be an appropriate technique to use in his treatment, depending on the nature of his problem, and that flooding is best used to...
fields.explanation: In flooding, the client is presented with stimuli that are associated with anxiety for long periods of time until they lose their capacity to evoke anxiety. A is incorrect because depression due to misconceptions is best treated with cognitive restructuring techniques. C is incorrect because flooding is usually used to eliminate a problematic behavior, including anxiety. Acquiring assertion skills is best accomplished through instructional techniques, modeling and behavioral rehearsal. D is incorrect because the disorientation in a person with delirium is biologically caused and the underlying biological dysfunction needs to be treated medically.

fields.text: You will be engaging a client in a time limited exploration of the client's unconscious psychodynamic conflicts. Your work with this client should be characterized by all of the following principles except one. Which one?
fields.explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. Sifneos and Malan, two leading proponents of the psychodynamic approach to brief therapy, state that the therapist must be able to simultaneously provide and balance confrontation and support. They do not call on the therapist to emphasize one over the other. The principles addressed in A, B and D are all key elements in this approach to therapy.

fields.text: You are working with a variety of clients who are new immigrants from Asian and Pacific Islander cultures. Many of these clients have been treated by indigenous healers in their native land, and some continue to see indigenous healers in your community. You will probably find that these healers seek to...
fields.explanation: Conditions that might be viewed as mental illness in Western cultures may be viewed as a disharmony between mind, body and spirit in Asian and Pacific Islander cultures. Indigenous healing practices seek to restore this harmony. A is incorrect because self-control and emotional restraint are valued. Use of will power and suppression of disturbing thoughts is likely to be sought, rather than encouraging their catharsis. C is incorrect because a sense of intergenerational dependence tends to be valued, and is not seen as a cause of psychic distress or social dysfunction. D is incorrect because indigenous healers are just as likely to be concerned with relieving distress as with enhancing social functioning.

fields.text: Prior to entering into a therapeutic relationship with your client you have an ethical obligation to clearly disclose and explain all of the following except one. Which one is the exception?
fields.explanation: The requirements stated in answers A, C and D are all clearly stated in the AAMFT Code of Ethics Sec. 7.2. B is the correct answer because you have no formal ethical obligation to justify your fee to the client. The client is free to accept or reject the fee.

fields.text: You are working with a client in long term, insight oriented Psychodynamic Psychotherapy in which the purpose of therapy is improved psychodynamic efficiency. This means that you and the client will be working toward...
fields.explanation: Improved efficiency means obtaining better results for less expenditure of energy. B is incorrect because psychic energy which is invested in either conflicts or fixations is inefficiently directed away from obtaining gratification in the real world. C is incorrect because Psychodynamic Psychotherapy may seek to bring preconscious material into consciousness, but this is not directly related to the concept of improved efficiency. D is incorrect because the concept of "improved efficiency" refers to a much broader array of issues than rapid development of a therapeutic alliance. This is only one example of how psychic energy might be efficiently invested.

fields.text: Your client becomes agitated and angry when you confront her with a discrepancy. Last week she told you that she was raised by her grandparents and today she told you that she was raised by her mother and stepfather. She now denies ever saying that she was raised by her grandparents. You should...
fields.explanation: A is incorrect because your client would simply claim that your notes were inaccurate. Also, it is likely that the treatment relationship would not be enhanced at a time like this by reminding the client that you are writing notes about them after every session. C is incorrect because it is not a genuine response. D is incorrect because the interpretation would not be very effective at this point in time while the client is denying that she is being deceptive. B is genuine without being overbearing on the client.

fields.text: You are interviewing a client who has a difficult time focusing on a specific problem or any specific issue. The client's comments tend to be vague, general and indirect. If you wanted to develop better focus in the interview, which of the following kinds of comments should you make?
fields.explanation: Closed questions and requests for descriptions tend to result in better focused answers. Open ended questions and requests for speculation, inferences and impressions tend to result in less focused answers. They are useful for engaging clients in deeper self-exploration but not for focus. A is an open ended question. B is an indirect question because it begs the same kind of response as an open ended question would. D is an even more broadly worded question than A. C is a more specific, and therefore delimited, request for a description of a day at work.

fields.text: In offering Rational Emotive Therapy to a client with a major depressive disorder, you will be...
fields.explanation: After "disputing" the client's false beliefs through rational confrontation, homework assignments are used to break negative behavior patterns and self-reinforcement is taught through learning covert self-statements, more constructive statements that clients learn to make to themselves. B is incorrect because, in R.E.T, the therapist disputes the beliefs and confronts the client with their invalidity rather than focusing on the client's need to maintain the belief. C is incorrect because the false beliefs are disputed before new beliefs are offered in their place. D is incorrect because R.E.T. focuses on the way in which thought causes emotions, not the other way around.

fields.text: You must make a child abuse report only if you develop a reasonable suspicion that child abuse has occurred as a result of information that you have received...
fields.explanation: Note the word "only" in the question. The Child Abuse Reporting Law states that a marriage and family therapist must report if you have "knowledge of or observe a child in his or her professional capacity or within the scope of his or her employment..." A is incorrect because your reasonable suspicion may be based on information from any source. B is incorrect for the same reason. D is incorrect information obtained in the course of private, personal relationships.

fields.text: A primary care physician has requested that you provide a consultation involving a thorough DSM Cultural Formulation. Your report back to the requestor should address all of the following issues except one. Which one?
fields.explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. The cultural identity of the client's significant others is not specifically addressed by the DSM framework for a Cultural Formulation, and it would be unethical to reveal information that is not needed to accomplish the purpose of the request. In order to determine the cultural identity of others the therapist would need to interview those others. This would be an expensive and cumbersome process. Most of the focus of the Cultural Formulation is on the client's experience of his or her own cultural reference group and what is known about the culture in general.

fields.text: A mother comes to see you with her nine year old daughter. She reveals that her husband has been fondling their daughter for the past six months. She wants you to meet with her husband and "give him the help he needs." Your first course of action should be to...
fields.explanation: This approach offers to empower the mother if she is ready to take that step. If not, then the therapist should make the call to protect the daughter and to comply with legal mandates. A is incorrect because it fosters an aura of secrecy and distance between therapist and client. C is incorrect because this action would be too stressful for most nine year olds in this situation and because the therapist doesn't have the authority to insist that the mother make the call. D is incorrect because it fails to offer the mother the opportunity to take a positive action on her daughter's, and her own, behalf.

fields.text: A marriage and family therapist is a covered entity under federal HIPAA regulations if the MFT...
fields.explanation: HIPAA regulations apply to any health care provider who engages in one or more electronic transmissions of private client information. This does not include telephone communications, or communications from one fax machine to another, but it does include communications between a fax machine and a computer. B is incorrect because paper records alone would not qualify a marriage and family therapist as a HIPAA covered entity. C is incorrect because submission of claims to an insurance plan would only qualify the therapist as a covered entity if communications of client information with the insurance plan were made by electronic means. D is incorrect because a single electronic transmission regarding a single client would qualify the therapist as a covered entity, regardless of the total number of clients served.

fields.text: Your client is a Latino man with a major depressive disorder. He tells you that he has seen a curandero who has also treated many others in his family. In his work with the curandero, you should expect to find that this client has likely experienced which of the following techniques?
fields.explanation: Curanderos typically have the aim of bringing the individual closer to the spiritual and religious culture of the Roman Catholic church. They do not generally practice exorcism or witchcraft. They do commonly use massage, cupping, "cleansing" rituals, herb remedies, prayer, advice, confession and reassurance.

fields.text: Your new client is an anxious and guilt ridden thirty-five year old fashion designer who is cautious about entering into new relationships. She also exhibits signs of a social phobia. In order to develop a therapeutic alliance with this client, which of the following should you use in the first few sessions?
fields.explanation: These three qualities are specifically designed to provide a therapeutic relationship process. They can be offered before a great deal of assessment information has been gathered. B is incorrect because during the first few sessions you don't know the client well enough to offer sound advice or realistic reassurance about the presenting problem. C is incorrect because these techniques will require considerable exposure prematurely. This is often associated with a sense of embarrassment, shame and premature termination. D is incorrect because confrontations and interpretations should generally wait until after a therapeutic alliance is established and the therapist has enough information about the client's personality and life situation to be able to make interpretations accurate, meaningful and well timed.

fields.text: Your new client is an anxious and guilt ridden thirty-five year old who has worked with several other therapists over the years. She feels that therapy has benefitted her, but that it never seems to be enough. She would like you to discuss possible adjunctive therapies if she is to begin work with you. Which of the following modalities should you consider as an appropriate adjunct to your psychotherapeutic work with this client?
fields.explanation: Biofeedback teaches a person to enhance their own alpha waves which are associated with relaxation. A is incorrect because electroconvulsive therapy, or shock therapy, is used to treat depression. B is incorrect because antabuse is an agonist therapy for treatment of alcoholism. D is incorrect because lithium carbonate is used to treat manic episodes in a bipolar disorder.

fields.text: Your client Bill G., a deeply depressed man, has been contemplating suicide. His risk is moderate and not imminent at the moment. Your approach to Bill should include all of the following except one. Which one?
fields.explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. You should be prepared to increase the frequency of visits or to set ad hoc appointments; also be available by phone and arrange for back up or crisis service contacts available when you are not. All other techniques noted should be used with suicidal clients.

fields.text: Your new client is a sixty five year old woman who was recently found to be the victim of isolation. This means that she has probably been subjected to...
fields.explanation: Isolation generally includes any intentional act that serves to separate the individual from others against his or her will. It includes preventing the dependent or elder adult from receiving mail or phone calls, falsely telling prospective visitors that the person is not present, false imprisonment, or physical restraint for the purpose of preventing a meeting with visitors. B is incorrect because it describes "neglect," not "isolation." C is incorrect because quarantine performed pursuant to a physician's instructions is explicitly excluded from the law regarding isolation. D is incorrect because physical restraint for the purpose of punishment is "physical abuse," not "isolation." See Sections 1510.43 through 1510.63 of the California Welfare and Institutions Code.

fields.text: In taking a Humanistic Existential approach to your depressed and anxious middle aged client, you will be focusing on...
fields.explanation: These theories prescribe such experiences as self- congruence and empathic understanding. They speak of "implementation of an attitude" rather than specific techniques. A is incorrect because these approaches deemphasize treatment planning and prescribe no particular planning techniques. C is incorrect because, again, the focus is what attitude a therapist should assume, not what a therapist should do in a procedural sense. D is incorrect because the Humanistic Existential therapist does not interpret a client's dreams, as a psychoanalytic therapist might do.

fields.text: You are about to form a new Gestalt Therapy group. In the course of your pregroup interviews you should inform them that they should follow all but one of the following principles when participating in the group. Which one?
fields.explanation: Note the words "all but one" in the question. Gestalt Therapy is focused on experience, not intellectual analysis. A is incorrect because acceptance of responsibility is a core value in that it contributes to developing a sense of integrity or wholeness. B is incorrect because risk taking is a core value. It refers to letting go of archaic response patterns and allowing new ones to emerge in the present circumstances. D is incorrect because this principle is a core value in all Humanistic Existential psychotherapies, including Gestalt.

fields.text: In the course of your long term, insight oriented therapy with a thirty-four year old psychologically sophisticated Latina client, which of the following is most likely to serve as a realistic, non-transference source of rebellion...
fields.explanation: Ambiguous and covert promises are dysfunctional communication patterns which would arouse frustration, anger and rebellion in most people. These are not considered transference reactions because they are not based on distortions brought to the current relationship by the client as a result of past experiences with others. B is incorrect because advice and direction are not a standard practice in many approaches to psychotherapy. If the client has sought psychotherapy and if these limitations are clearly explained to the client during early sessions, rebellion against this limitation would be an unrealistic transference. C and D are incorrect for the same reason that B is incorrect. They reflect standard psychotherapy practices which the client is free to accept or reject by terminating the psychotherapy relationship.

fields.text: You are teaching the anxious and overbearing parents of an unruly five year old child to use negative reinforcement as a way of improving the child's behavior. This means that you will be teaching your clients to...
fields.explanation: Many people confuse "negative reinforcement" with punishment. Negative reinforcement creates a positive experience for the individual by removing something that had previously been aversive, annoying, or painful. For example, if a child has been confined to his room until he finishes his homework, by allowing the child to leave his room when homework is finished he has been negatively I reinforced. Eliminating a previously imposed punishment constitutes negative reenforcement. B is incorrect because it describes punishment, not negative reinforcement. C is incorrect for reasons noted above. D is incorrect because anticipatory guidance involves instruction and rational discussion, not specifically reinforcement.

fields.text: You are conducting a cognitive assessment as part of a mental status exam for your new client, a seventy-year old woman living in a nursing home. When you ask the client "How many nickels are there in $1.35?" you are testing for...
fields.explanation: When conducting a mental status exam, calculation questions test a person's ability to concentrate and focus attention through the steps of the calculation. But the client's fund of information is being tested as well. If a client had never learned how to divide, good concentration and attention span will not produce the correct answer. That's why B is incorrect. C is incorrect because level of consciousness refers to a person's capacity to focus and shift, as well as maintain attention. A client's degree of alertness and wakefulness should be apparent from simple interview questions and would not require a calculation test. D is incorrect because recent memory refers to a person's ability to recall information over a period of several hours to several days. Tests of calculation require use of memory, primarily immediate retention and recall, not recent memory.

fields.text: You are reviewing the clinical record of a new client, a seventy-year old woman who lives in a nursing home. The clinical record of her mental status exam states that she is "oriented times three." You should take this to mean that...
fields.explanation: A is incorrect because "oriented times three" refers to a person's orientation at a point in time, not over the course of time. B is incorrect because orientation to procedure is not an aspect of the mental status exam. A person may be asked to follow a set of procedures, such as arranging matchsticks in a particular geometric pattern, but this is a test for apraxia or disturbed executive function, not orientation. D is incorrect because, although these are mental status exam issues, they are not matters of orientation.

fields.text: As an MFT working in a county operated mental health service system, the consent of the client must be obtained before sharing confidential information with...
fields.explanation: This awkwardly worded requirement is found in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 5328 which governs confidentiality in public mental health service systems. The law states that information and records shall be disclosed only in certain situations. Among them is this. "In communications between qualified professional persons in the provision of services or appropriate referrals, or in the course of conservatorship proceedings." The law then places a restriction on communications between certain professional persons. The consent of the patient, or his or her guardian or conservator shall be obtained before information or records may be disclosed by a professional person employed by a facility to a professional person not employed by the facility who does not have the medical or psychological responsibility for the patient's care? A and B are incorrect because the law allows sharing of confidential information among staff of a program and even staff of a service system, as long as the client is informed at the outset of treatment that such sharing of information is the practice. D is incorrect because information may be shared, even without the client's consent, when the receiving person has medical or psychological responsibility for the client. The clients consent must be obtained before sharing information with others who do not have medical or psychological responsibility for the client.

fields.text: In the course of developing treatment plans with your clients you are guided by principles drawn from Solution Focused Therapy, in which a client's well formed goals should have presence, not absence. Your treatment plan goals should be similar to which of the following examples?
fields.explanation: Presence means that goals should be stated in the affirmative, indicating what should be present when the goal is achieved. Feeling relaxed is what is present when anxiety is reduced. B is incorrect because both "increase confidence" and "improve self esteem" are examples of presence. C is incorrect because both "improve social skills" and "improve quality of social relationships" are also examples of presence. D is incorrect because "reduce anxiety" is an example of absence, not presence. Also, "increase self-assertion skills" is an example of presence, not absence.

fields.text: You are working with a cyclothymic client whose depressed moods are clearly associated with dysfunctional automatic thoughts. In order to assist the client to modify these automatic thoughts using Cognitive Therapy you should first use which of the following techniques?
fields.explanation: Thought recording is a technique used for identifying automatic thoughts. These thoughts must first be identified before the evidence for their validity can be examined (B), or before alternatives can be generated (A). C is incorrect because reattribution is also an intervention technique used to correct erroneous attributions of cause-effect relationships.

fields.text: As a staff member in a county mental health service system, if a client consents to the release of confidential information to a designated person, the MFT...
fields.explanation: The Welfare and Institutions Code Sec. 5328 states that confidential information shall be disclosed only under certain conditions. Among them is this. "When the patient, with the approval of the...licensed marriage and family therapist, who is in charge of the patient, designates persons to whom information or records may be released, except that nothing in this article shall be construed to compel a...licensed marriage and family therapist...or other professional person to reveal information that has been given to him or her in confidence by members of a patient's family." A is incorrect because most public mental health clients are clinically and legally competent to give informed consent, and approval by a family member is not necessary. C is incorrect because the therapist may release the information but is not compelled to do so. Clients often give consent to release more information than is necessary to release in order to accomplish the clients own purpose. D is incorrect because most clients are presumed to be competent. A formal documented evaluation is not required every time the client gives consent, unless there are indicators that the individual might not be competent.

fields.text: Your 21 year old client is preoccupied with trying to determine the subtle motives of authority figures, including professors and her employer. Her preoccupation stems from an unresolved fixation arising from her relationship with an exploitive and harsh foster parent during her elementary school years. This client's fixation involves a problem of...
fields.explanation: Cathexis refers to the way in which psychic energy becomes invested in a particular object or issue. A fixation is a cathexis that remains long after there is any adaptive purpose to the investment of psychic energy. A is incorrect because secondary process thinking refers to logical and reality oriented thinking. B is incorrect because psychic structure refers to the id, ego and superego. A fixation is not a structure but a process. D is incorrect because the superego is the aspect of the mind concerned with conscience or morality as it was learned in childhood. Fixations may or may not become established due to morality concerns.

fields.text: Your client is troubled by a sense of emptiness, identity confusion, and the meaninglessness of life. From the perspective of Psychosynthesis, a Humanistic Existential Psychotherapy approach, you should help your client to achieve...
fields.explanation: Dis-identification from all that is not the authentic self means giving up the distortions of defensiveness and false identifications with fragmented or partial aspects of self. A is incorrect because repression of the sublime refers to the failure to accept and manifest our highest nature. It is something to be overcome, not to be achieved in therapy. C is incorrect because the concept of mobile fixations is an inherently contradictory combination of concepts from Psychodynamic Theory. D is incorrect because unconditional positive regard is a quality the therapist must bring to the therapeutic process. It is not necessarily a goal for the client to achieve.
